{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:AE''' is the entry for the [[United Arab Emirates]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for the United Arab Emirates, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[emirates of the United Arab Emirates|7 emirates]]. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|AE}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of the United Arab Emirates. The second part is two letters. ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision Name ([[Arabic language|ar]])
(BGN/PCGN 1956) ! Local variant ! Subdivision name ([[Arabic language|ar]])
For reference only, Arabic name in Arabic script not included in the ISO 3166-2 standard. |- | {{mono|AE-AZ}} | {{flag|Abū Z̧aby}} | Abu Dhabi | أبو ظبي |- | {{mono|AE-AJ}} | {{sort| Ajman|{{flag|‘Ajmān}}}} | | إمارة عجمانّ |- | {{mono|AE-FU}} | {{flag|Al Fujayrah}} | Fujairah | الفجيرة |- | {{mono|AE-SH}} | {{flag|Ash Shāriqah}} | Sharjah | إمارة الشارقةّ |- | {{mono|AE-DU}} | {{flag|Dubayy}} | Dubai | دبي |- | {{mono|AE-RK}} | {{flag|Ra’s al Khaymah}} | Ras Al Khaimah | إمارة رأس الخيمة |- | {{mono|AE-UQ}} | {{flag|Umm al Qaywayn}} | Umm Al Quwain | أمّ القيوين |} ; Notes ==Changes== The following changes to the entry have been announced by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998. ISO stopped issuing newsletters in 2013. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter |- | id="I-2" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_i-2_en.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter I-2}}] | 2002-05-21 | Spelling correction in AE-RK |- | id="I-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_i-3_en.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter I-3}}] | 2002-08-20 | Error correction: Spelling correction in AE-AZ |- | [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:AE Online Browsing Platform (OBP)] | 2015-11-27 | Change of spelling of AE-AJ, AE-RK; addition of local variation of AE-FK, AE-RK, AE-UQ; update List Source |} ==See also== * [[Subdivisions of the United Arab Emirates]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (A-C)#AE: United Arab Emirates|FIPS region codes of the United Arab Emirates]] * Neighbouring countries: [[ISO_3166-2:OM|OM]], [[ISO_3166-2:SA|SA]]. ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:AE ISO Online Browsing Platform: AE] * [http://www.statoids.com/uae.html United Arab Emirates], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:AE]] [[Category:Emirates of the United Arab Emirates|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:United Arab Emirates geography-related lists]]

{{About|the ancient region in the south of Europe}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Illyria | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- ISO 639-2 code e.g. "fr" for French. If more than one, use {{lang}} instead --> | settlement_type = [[Historical region]] | image_skyline = | image_alt = | image_caption = | image_flag = | flag_alt = | image_seal = | seal_alt = | image_shield = | shield_alt = | nickname = | motto = | image_map = Illyrian Tribes (English).svg | map_alt = | map_caption = Approximate area settled by Illyrians in antiquity. | pushpin_map = | pushpin_label_position = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | coordinates = | coor_pinpoint = | coordinates_footnotes = | subdivision_type = Area | subdivision_name = W [[Balkan Peninsula]] | subdivision_type1 = | subdivision_name1 = | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | subdivision_type3 = | subdivision_name3 = <!-- ALL fields with measurements have automatic unit conversion --> <!-- for references: use <ref> tags --> | area_footnotes = | area_urban_footnotes = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_rural_footnotes = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_metro_footnotes = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_magnitude = <!-- <ref> </ref> --> | area_note = | area_water_percent = | area_rank = | area_blank1_title = | area_blank2_title = <!-- square kilometers --> | area_total_km2 = | area_land_km2 = | area_water_km2 = | area_urban_km2 = | area_rural_km2 = | area_metro_km2 = | area_blank1_km2 = | area_blank2_km2 = <!-- hectares --> | area_total_ha = | area_land_ha = | area_water_ha = | area_urban_ha = | area_rural_ha = | area_metro_ha = | area_blank1_ha = | area_blank2_ha = | length_km = | width_km = | dimensions_footnotes = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = | population_footnotes = | population_total = | population_as_of = | population_density_km2 = auto | population_demonym = | population_note = | timezone1 = | utc_offset1 = | timezone1_DST = | utc_offset1_DST = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | footnotes = }} In [[classical antiquity]], '''Illyria''' ({{IPAc-en|ɪ|ˈ|l|ɪər|i|ə}}; {{lang-grc|Ἰλλυρία}}, ''Illyría'' or {{lang|grc|Ἰλλυρίς}}, ''Illyrís'';<ref>''Illyría'' and ''Illyrís'' respectively</ref><ref>Polybius. ''Histories'', [http://old.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0233:book=1:chapter=13 1.13.1]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.</ref> {{lang-la|Illyria}},<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Charlton T.|last2=Short|first2=Charles|title=A Latin Dictionary|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059%3Aentry%3D%2321597|chapter=Illyria}}</ref> see also ''[[Illyricum (Roman province)|Illyricum]])'' was a region in the western part of the [[Balkan Peninsula]] inhabited by the [[Illyrians]]. At least most of them spoke [[Illyrian languages]], a group of [[Indo-European languages]], which in ancient times perhaps had speakers in southern Italy.<ref>If the [[Messapian language]] was close enough to the Illyrian languages to be considered an Illyrian language, then Illyrian would also have been spoken in southern [[Italy]].</ref>
The [[Prehistory of Southeastern Europe|prehistory]] of Illyria and the [[Illyrians]] is known from archaeological evidence. The [[Roman Republic|Romans]] conquered the region in 168 BC in the aftermath of the [[Illyrian Wars]].
The Roman term '''Illyris''' (distinct from '''''Illyria''''') was sometimes used to define an area north of the [[Aous]] valley, most notably [[Illyris proper]].<ref>{{harvnb|Boardman|1982|p=623}}.</ref>
==Etymology== In [[Greek mythology]], the name of Illyria is [[Etiology|aetiologically]] traced to [[Illyrius]], the son of [[Cadmus]] and [[Harmonia (mythology)|Harmonia]], who eventually ruled Illyria and became the eponymous ancestor of the Illyrians.<ref>{{harvnb|Grimal|Maxwell-Hyslop|1996|p=230}}.</ref> A later version of the myth identifies [[Polyphemus]] and [[Acis and Galatea (mythology)|Galatea]] as parents of [[Celtus]], [[Galas]], and [[Illyrius]].<ref>{{harvnb|Grimal|Maxwell-Hyslop|1996|p=168}}</ref>
Ancient Greek writers used the name "Illyrian" to describe peoples between the [[Liburnians]] and [[Epirus]].{{sfn|Wilkes|1969|p=5}} Fourth-century BC Greek writers clearly separated the people along the Adriatic coast from the Illyrians, and only in the 1st century AD was "Illyrian" used as a general term for all the peoples across the Adriatic.{{sfn|Wilkes|1969|p=161}} Writers also spoke of "Illyrians in the strict sense of the word"; [[Pomponius Mela]] (43 AD) the ''stricto sensu'' Illyrians lived north of the [[Taulantii]] and [[Enchele]], on the Adriatic shore;<ref name="Katicic1976">{{cite book|author=Radoslav Katicic|title=Ancient Languages of the Balkans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kSkjAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA158|date=1 January 1976|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-156887-4|pages=158–}}</ref> [[Pliny the Elder]] used "properly named Illyrians"{{sfn|Wilkes|1969|p=161}} (''Illyrii proprii/proprie dicti'') for a small people{{sfn|Wilkes|1969|p=161}} south of [[Epidaurum]],{{sfn|Wilkes|1969|p=161}} or between [[Epidaurum]] (now [[Cavtat]]) and [[Lissus]] (now [[Lezhë]]).<ref name="Katicic1976"/> In the Roman period, ''Illyricum'' was used for the area between the Adriatic and Danube.{{sfn|Wilkes|1969|p=5}} <ref name="Kos2005">{{cite book|author=Marjeta Šašel Kos|title=Appian and Illyricum|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=opBpAAAAMAAJ|year=2005|publisher=Narodni Muzej Slovenije|isbn=978-961-6169-36-3|page=231}}</ref>
==Kingdoms== {{Main|List of rulers of Illyria|Dardanian Kingdom}}
The earliest recorded Illyrian kingdom was that of the [[Enchele]] in the 8th century BC.<ref>{{harvnb|Stipčević|2002|pages=46–47}}.</ref> The era in which we observe other Illyrian kingdoms begins approximately at 400 BC and ends at 167 BC.<ref>{{harvnb|Wilkes|1995|p=298}}.</ref> The Autariatae under [[Pleurias]] (337 BC) were considered to have been a kingdom.<ref>{{harvnb|Lewis|Boardman|1994|p=785}}.</ref> The Kingdom of the [[Ardiaei]] began at 230 BC and ended at 167 BC.<ref>{{harvnb|Wilkes|1969|p=13}}.</ref> The most notable Illyrian kingdoms and dynasties were those of [[Bardyllis]] of the [[Dardani]] and of [[Agron of Illyria|Agron]] of the [[Ardiaei]] who created the last and best-known Illyrian kingdom.<ref>{{harvnb|Kipfer|2000|p=251}}.</ref> Agron ruled over the Ardiaei and had extended his rule to other tribes as well.<ref>{{harvnb|Hammond|1993|p=104}}.</ref> As for the Dardanians, they always had separate domains from the rest of the [[Illyrians]].<ref>{{harvnb|Papazoglu|1978|p=216}}.</ref>
The Illyrian kingdoms were composed of small areas within the region of Illyria. Only the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] ruled the entire region. The internal organization of the south Illyrian kingdoms points to imitation of their neighbouring Greek kingdoms and influence from the Greek and [[Hellenistic]] world in the growth of their [[urban area|urban]] centres.<ref>{{harvnb|Wilkes|1995|p=237}}.</ref> [[Polybius]] gives as an image of society within an Illyrian kingdom as peasant infantry fought under aristocrats which he calls in Greek ''Polydynastae'' (Greek: Πολυδυνάστες) where each one controlled a town within the kingdom.<ref>{{harvnb|Wilkes|1995|p=127}}.</ref> The monarchy was established on hereditary lines and Illyrian rulers used marriages as a means of alliance with other powers.<ref>{{harvnb|Wilkes|1995|p=167}}.</ref> [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] (23–79 AD) writes that the people that formed the nucleus of the Illyrian kingdom were 'Illyrians proper' or [[List of ancient tribes in Illyria#Illyrii Proprie Dicti|Illyrii Proprie Dicti]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wilkes|1995|p=216}}.</ref> They were the [[Taulantii]], the [[Pleraei]], the [[Endirudini]], [[Sasaei]], [[Grabaei]] and the [[Labeatae]]. These later joined to form the [[Docleatae]].
==Roman and Byzantine rule== {{Main|Illyricum (Roman province)|Praetorian prefecture of Illyricum}}
The Romans defeated Gentius, the last king of Illyria, at [[Scodra]] (in present-day Albania) in 168 BC and captured him, bringing him to Rome in 165 BC. Four client-republics were set up, which were in fact ruled by Rome. Later, the region was directly governed by Rome and organized as a [[Roman province|province]], with Scodra as its capital.
[[File:Prefecture of Illyricum map.png|thumb|left|150px|The Prefecture of Illyricum 375-379 (light green).]]
The Roman province of ''Illyricum'' replaced the formerly independent kingdom of Illyria. It stretched from the [[Drin River|Drilon]] river in modern [[Albania]] to [[Istria]] ([[Croatia]]) in the west and to the [[Sava]] river ([[Bosnia & Herzegovina]]) in the north. [[Salona]] (near modern [[Split (city)|Split]] in Croatia) functioned as its capital.
After crushing a [[Great Illyrian Revolt|revolt]] of [[Pannonians]] and [[Daesitiates]], Roman administrators dissolved the province of Illyricum and divided its lands between the new provinces of [[Pannonia]] in the north and [[Dalmatia (Roman province)|Dalmatia]] in the south. Although this division occurred in 10 AD, the term ''Illyria'' remained in use in [[Late Latin]] and throughout the medieval period. After the [[division of the Roman Empire]], the [[bishops of Thessalonica]] appointed papal vicars for Illyricum. The first of these vicars is said to have been Bishop [[Acholius]] or Ascholius (died 383 or 384), the friend of [[St. Basil]]. In the 5th century, the bishops of Illyria withdrew from communion with Rome, without attaching themselves to Constantinople, and remained for a time independent, but in 515, forty Illyrian bishops renewed their loyalty to Rome by declaring allegiance to [[Pope Hormisdas]]. The patriarchs of Constantinople succeeded in bringing Illyria under their jurisdiction in the 8th century.<ref name="Catholic Encyclopedia">{{harvnb|Lins|1910|loc="Illyria"}}.</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:Coa Croatia Country Illyria History.svg|thumb|right|135px|Fictional "coat of arms of Illyria" in the 17th-century [[Fojnica Armorial]].]] The name ''Illyria'' only disappears from the historical record after the [[Ottoman invasion of the Balkans]] in the 15th century, and re-emerges in the 17th century, acquiring a new significance in the [[Ottoman-Habsburg wars|Ottoman–Habsburg Wars]], as [[Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold I]] designated as the "Illyrian nation" the South Slavs in Hungarian territory.<ref name="Catholic Encyclopedia"/> Several armorials of the Early modern period, popularly called the "[[Illyrian Armorials]]", depicted fictional coats of arms of Illyria.
The name ''Illyria'' was revived by [[Napoleon]] for the [[Illyrian Provinces]] that were incorporated into the [[First French Empire|French Empire]] from 1809 to 1813, and the [[Kingdom of Illyria (1816–1849)]] was part of [[Austria]] until 1849, after which time it was not used in the reorganised [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]].
The [[Illyrian movement]] was a pan-South Slavist ([[Yugoslavism]]) cultural and political campaign by a group of young Croatian and Serbian intellectuals during the first half of the 19th century.
== In popular culture ==
[[William Shakespeare]] chose a fictionalized Illyria as the setting for his play ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' (In the modernised film spoof ''[[She's the Man]]'', this function is served by "Illyria High School" in California). An extensive history of Illyria by [[Charles du Fresne, sieur du Cange]], was published by Joseph [[House of Keglević|Keglevich]] in 1746.<ref>{{harvnb|du Fresne|1746|p=1}}.</ref> Shakespeare also mentioned the region in the [[Henry VI, Part 2|Part 2]] of the play ''[[Henry VI (play)|Henry VI]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Henry VI, part 2: Entire Play|url=http://shakespeare.mit.edu/2henryvi/full.html|website=shakespeare.mit.edu}}</ref>
The land of Illyria is the setting for [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]'s ''[[Les Mains Sales]]'' and in [[Lloyd Alexander]]'s ''The Illyrian Adventure''.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
[[John Hawkes (novelist)|John Hawkes]]' 1970 novel ''The Blood Oranges'' is set in a fictionalized Illyria.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hawkes|first=John|last2=Scholes|first2=Robert|year=1972|title=A Conversation on "The Blood Oranges" between John Hawkes and Robert Scholes |jstor=1345277|journal=NOVEL: A Forum on Fiction|volume=5|issue= 3|pages=203-204, 197-207|doi=10.2307/1345277}}</ref>
In the television show ''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]'', Illyria was the name of an Old One (an ancient and powerful demon) who was resurrected in the final season.
In [[Jacqueline Carey]]'s book ''[[Kushiel's Chosen]]'', Illyria is featured as a vassal nation to La Serenissima (Venice).

{{Infobox mountain | name = Jabal an-Nabi Shu'aib | native_name = جَبَل ٱلنَّبِي شُعَيْب {{ar icon}} | photo = | photo_size = 300px | photo_caption = | elevation_m = 3666 | elevation_ref = [http://www.peaklist.org/WWlists/ultras/mideast.html "Arabian peninsula and Middle East"] Peaklist.org. Retrieved 2011-11-20. | prominence_m = 3326 | prominence_ref =
[[List of peaks by prominence|Ranked 62nd]] | map = Yemen | map_caption = Location of Jabal an-Nabi Shu'aib in Yemen | map_size = | label_position = right | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]]
[[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]] | location = [[Sana'a Governorate]], [[Yemen]] | range = | coordinates = {{coord|15|16|45|N|43|58|33|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = | age = | last_eruption = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }} '''''Jabal An-Nabī Shuʿayb''''' ({{lang-ar|جَبَل ٱلنَّبِي شُعَيْب|lit=Mountain of the Prophet Shu'aib}}) is a mountain of the [[Sarawat Mountains|Sarawat range]] located in [[Sana'a Governorate]], [[Yemen]]. It is the highest mountain of the country and the [[Arabian Peninsula]]. It is one of the most [[prominence|prominent]] peaks in the world and the [[List of Ultras of West Asia|third most prominent peak in the Middle East]]. == Description == Its elevation is often reported to be 3,760 metres, but this is not supported by [[SRTM]] data or more recent cartographic sources.[http://www.pbase.com/bmcmorrow/image/41334608 Map at pbase.com] Retrieved 2011-11-20 The height of the mountain is {{convert|3666|m|ft|0}}, and is located near the Yemeni capital city of [[Sana'a]]. Yemen's second highest peak, [[Jabal Tiyal]], is nearly equidistant from the capital as Jabal an-Nabi Shu'aib is. The mountain may seem like a rocky knoll from observation center like the Sana'a-Al Hudayda highway, but from its western face it is a massive mountain rising from about {{convert|1500|–|1600|m|ft|abbr=on}}. This side of the mountain halts clouds burdened with precipitation, causing that side to be relatively fertile. Atop the mountain is a military post with a radar and the shrine of the [[Prophets and messengers in Islam|Islamic ''Nabī'']] ([[Prophet]]) [[Shuaib|Shu'ayb]]. It is relatively difficult to be allowed to its summit, but restrictions have eased as of late.{{Clarify|date=September 2015}} Although the summit is not snow-capped like its counterparts in northern [[Lebanon]] and [[Syria]], there have been reports of snow on the peak and frost in the winter. Wind speeds are very high at the summit.{{cn|date=November 2018}} ==See also== * [[South Arabia]] * [[List of elevation extremes by country]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.peakbagger.com/peak.aspx?pid=10477 "Jabal an Nabī Shu‘aib, Yemen" on Peakbagger.com] * [http://www.mountain-forecast.com/peaks/Jabal-an-Nabi-Shu-ayb/forecasts/3666 Mountain-forecast.com] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZNRCpNTvymo أين يقع جبل النبي شعيب] ([[YouTube]], in Arabic) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DsUGWdiOrQA اعرف بلدك: جبل النبي الشعيب.. أعلى قمة جبلية في الشرق الأوسط] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HIl2g7Vg1V4 النزول من جبل النبي شعيب] {{Highest points of Asia}} [[Category:Mountains of Yemen|Nabi Shuayb]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] {{Yemen-geo-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Juan Olazábal Ramery | image = Juan Olazabal.JPG | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Juan Olazábal Ramery | birth_date = 1860 | birth_place = [[Irún]], Spain | death_date = 1937 | death_place = [[Bilbao]], Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = journalist | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[:es:Partido Católico Nacional|Partido Católico Nacional]], [[Comunión Tradicionalista-Integrista]], [[Comunión Tradicionalista]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }}
'''Juan Olazábal Ramery''' (1860–1937), was a Spanish [[carlism|Carlist]] politician.
==Family and youth== [[File:1872 nafarroa.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|1872: a Carlist, a boy, a [[pottok]] and a dog]] Juan José León Félix Ramón Olazábal Ramery was born to a very distinguished [[Gipuzkoa]]n dynasty,<ref>see Ana Galdós Monfort, Mercedes Tranche Iparraguirre, ''Los Olazábal. Un ejemplo del surgimiento, persistencia y transformación de las élites locales en Irun (Siglos XV-XX)'', [in:] ''Boletín de estudios del Bidasoa'', 26 (2010), pp. 167-183</ref> much branched and intemarried with a number of other well known local families.<ref>see ''euskalnet'' service available [http://www.euskalnet.net/laviana/gen_bascas/Olazábal.htm here]; see also ''Geni'' genealogical service [http://www.geni.com/people/Juan-Antonio-Olaz%C3%A1bal-Arteaga/6000000018514898052 here], ''Geneanet'' service [http://gw.geneanet.org/sanchiz?lang=en;p=juan+jose+leon+felix+ramon;n=Olazábal+ramery here], and much worse ''Geneallnet'' entry [http://geneall.net/pt/nome/2167632/juan-de-Olazábal-y-ramery/ here]</ref> His father, [[Juan Antonio Olazábal Arteaga]], held a number of estates in Eastern part of the province.<ref>Javier Real Cuesta, ''El Carlismo Vasco 1876-1900'', Madrid 1985, {{ISBN|978-84-323-0510-8}}, pp. 117-118, 250</ref> Following his early death in 1867,<ref>''Juan Antonio Olazábal Arteaga'' entry at ''Geni'' service [http://www.geni.com/people/Juan-Antonio-Olaz%C3%A1bal-Arteaga/6000000018514898052 here]</ref> Juan and his siblings were raised by their mother, Prudencia Ramery Zuzuarregui.<ref>there seems to be some confusion as to the correct spelling of her segundo apellido. Most sources prefer the “Zuzuarregui” version, see e.g. the ''Ramery y Zuzuarregui, Liborio'' entry at ''Indice Historico de Diputados'' at the official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2893320%29.NDIP. here]. There are authors, however, who prefer the “Zuazarregui” version, see José Antonio Vaca de Osma, ''Los vascos en la historia de España'', Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|8432130958}}, 9788432130953, p. 178. Some sources are inconsistent; the genealogical ''Geni'' service refers to most of the siblings “Zuazarregui”, with the exception of Prudencia, who is named “Zuzuarregui”, see [http://www.geni.com/people/Prudencia-Ramery-Zuzuarregui/6000000018514694730 here]. The contemporary press used "Zuzuarregui", see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.01.94 [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000175745&page=1 here]</ref> At the outbreak of the [[Third Carlist War]] the family sought refuge in [[France]].<ref>Jose Urbano Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' online, available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/116770 here]</ref> Following their return to Spain Juan was educated in the [[Jesuit]] college in [[Orduña]], where he met and befriended [[Sabino Arana]],<ref>'' Euskera: se empieza inventando un idioma…'' [in:] ''Pais Vasco'' 01.02.05 available [http://nacionalismo.blogs.com/byebyespain/2005/02/euskera_se_empi.html here]</ref> to proceed with law studies in another Jesuit institute, [[Colegio del Pasaxe]] in the [[Galicia (Spain)|Galician]] [[A Guarda]].<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> He then moved to [[:es:Universidad de Madrid|Universidad Central]] in [[Madrid]],<ref>in an open letter of 1884 he is signed as "estudiante católico de Madrid", ''El Siglo Futuro'' 11.12.84, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000086890&page=1 here]</ref> to graduate in 1885.<ref>in ''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.03.85 he is already signed as "licenciado", see [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000088877&page=1 here]</ref>
Though the family in some sources is described as Carlist,<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> in fact its different branches adhered to different political options. Juan’s paternal uncle, [[Ramón Olazábal Arteaga]], as [[Colonel|coronel]] of [[Miquelet (militia)|miqueletes]]<ref>Francisco Apalategui Igarzabal, ''Karlisten eta liberalen gerra-kontaerak'', San Sebastian 2005, {{ISBN|8479074876}}, pp. 41, 43, available [http://www.euskaltzaindia.net/dok/iker_jagon_tegiak/auspoa/59323.pdf here]</ref> sided with the [[Isabella II of Spain|Isabelinos]] during the Third Carlist War, growing to commander of the entire formation<ref>Serapio Mugica Zufiria, ''Geografía de Guipúzcoa'', available at Instituto Geografico Vasco site [http://www.ingeba.org/klasikoa/geografi/mug301/g765779.htm here]</ref> and also the civil governor of Irun.<ref>Apalategui 2005, p. 298</ref> On the other hand, Juan’s maternal uncle, [[Liborio Ramery Zuzuarregui]],<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery'', see also ''Liborio Ramery Zuzuarregui'' entry at ''Geni'' service [http://www.geni.com/people/Liborio-Ramery-Zuazarregui/6000000018515995922 here]</ref> made his name as a Carlist politician, Gipzukoan deputy to the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] and a [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] writer. A distant relative from paternal branch, [[Tirso Olazábal Lardizábal|Tirso de Olazábal y Lardizábal]],<ref>Juan de Olazábal Ramery (b. 1702) and Domingo de Olazábal Ramery (b. 1703) were brothers; Juan Olazábal Ramery was the great-great-great-grandson of the former, while Tirso de Olazábal y Lardizábal was the great-great-grandson of the latter, see euskalnet; for simplified genealogical tree showing relationship between the two, see [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Olazabal.JPG here]</ref> became head of Gipuzkoan Carlism and one of the national party leaders.<ref>Carlos Cortabarria Igartua, ''Tirso de Olazábal Arbelaiz Lardizabal'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/116718 here], see also genealogical tree and numerous detailed info pieces at Luis Maria Zavala (ed.), ''La sociedad Vasca del siglo XIX en la correpondencia del archivo de la casa de Zavala'', Lasarte 2008, {{ISBN|9788496288706}}, p. 67 and passim</ref> It was rather the influence of Juan’s maternal family, especially Liborio, which combined with the Jesuit education formed him as a Carlist. Juan Olazábal has never married and had no children. Some members of the Olazábal family were active as Carlist politicians in the early Francoist era, though they were very distant Juan’s relatives.<ref>the best known is Rafael Olazábal Eulate, active in Carlism between the 1930s and 1950s, see ''euskalnet''</ref>
==Early career== [[File:Ramón Nocedal, de Manuel Compañy.jpg|thumbnail|170px]] Already as a student Olazábal engaged in public activity taking part in Carlist-sponsored Catholic initiatives,e.g. protests against [[krausism]]-flavored heterodoxy in education<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 11.12.84 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000086890&page=1 here]</ref> or against promotion of figures like [[Giordano Bruno]];<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.03.85 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000088877&page=1 here]</ref> instead, he advocated Catholic orthodoxy as fundament of public education in Spain. In 1888 both Olazábal Ramery brothers, Juan and Javier,<ref>he was head of public works department in Gipuzkoa, civil engineer specialising in road construction, and head of Integrism in Toledo; died in 1926, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.12.27 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000431529&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 19.04.28 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000441126&page=1 here] and ''El Siglo Futuro'' 10.01.89 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000204504&page=1 here]. His sister Caya was also a Carlist activist, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.05.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000274126&page=1 here]</ref> defected from mainstream Carlism and joined its breakaway branch led by [[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón Nocedal]], known as [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrism]];<ref>in historiography the Integrist secession is interpreted in 4 different ways. Jordi Canal presents 3 of them: as a result of personal conflict between Nocedal and [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]], as a result of ideological conflict within Carlism, as a result of wider European trend - see Jordi Canal i Morell, ''La masonería en el discurso integrista español a finales del siglo XIX: Ramón Nocedal y Romea'', [in:] José Antonio Ferrer Benimeli (ed.), ''Masonería, revolución y reacción'', Alicante 1990, {{ISBN|844047606X}}, p. 774, also his ''Las “muertes” y las “resurrecciones” del carlismo. Reflexiones sobre la escisión integrista de 1888'', [in:] ''Ayer'' 38 (2000), pp. 115-136. Another proposal is advanced by Clemente, who presents Integrism as antidemocratic ideology of the wealthy few who parasitised on popular and democratic Carlism, see Josep Carles Clemente, ''Los días fugaces. El carlismo, de las guerras civiles a la transición'', Cuenca 2013, {{ISBN|9788495414243}}, p. 28, also his ''Breve historia de las guerras carlistas'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|8499671691}}, 9788499671697, pp. 7-18</ref> they followed the example of their uncle Liborio, who entered the Integrist executive as secretario of junta central.<ref>Jordi Canal i Morell, ''Banderas blancas, boinas rojas: una historia política del carlismo, 1876-1939'', Madrid 2006, {{ISBN|8496467341}}, 9788496467347, p. 88</ref> In 1889 they were already active in various minor Integrist public initiatives.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 17.06.89 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000134135&page=1 here]</ref> Juan returned to Gipuzkoa, building the party structures and mobilising its popular support in the province, which soon turned out to be a national Integrist stronghold.<ref>detailed account in María Obieta Villalonga, ''Los integristas guipuzcoanos. Desarrollo y organización del Partido Católico Nacional en Guipúzcoa (1888-1898)'', Bilbao 1996, {{ISBN|8470863266}}, 9788470863264</ref> In the [[Spanish general election, 1891|1891 elections]] the party gained 2 mandates in the province, one conquered by Juan’s uncle Liborio<ref>''Ramery y Zuzuarregui, Liborio'' at ''Indice Historico de Diputados''</ref> and one by the party leader Nocedal.<ref>see Nocedal y Romea, Ramon entry for 1891 at Indice Historico de Diputados at the official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2880300%29.NDIP. here]</ref> Since at that time Integrism and mainstream Carlism competed with vehement hostility, the latter success looked triumphant: Nocedal defeated the Gipuzkoan mainstream Carlist leader, Tirso Olazábal.<ref>Agustín Fernández Escudero, El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012, p. 237</ref> Nocedal was also re-elected in the subsequent elections of 1893.<ref>see Nocedal y Romea, Ramon entry for 1893 at Indice Historico de Diputados at the official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=3-3&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2880300%29.NDIP. here]</ref>
Following the death of Liborio Ramery in 1894,<ref>see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.01.94 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000175745&page=1 here]</ref> Juan Olazábal took his place in provincial party leadership. The same year he was already representing the province at national party gatherings,<ref>together with Benito Ameztoy, Ignacio Echaide and Luis Maria Echeverria, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 03.08.94 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000177802&page=1 here]</ref> hosting party meetings at his [[Mundaiz (estate in San Sebastian)|Mundaiz]] estate in 1895<ref>''La Iberia'' 15.07.95, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001765151&page=2 here]</ref> and formally growing to segundo adjunto of the Gipuzkoan branch in 1896.<ref>presided by Ramón Zavala y Salazar, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 06.07.96 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000185894&page=1 here]</ref> He was engaged in negotiations with other parties during local electoral campaigns. An alliance with the conservatives, known as [[Union Vasconavarra]], produced 3 Integrist mandates into the [[Donostia-San Sebastián, Guipúzcoa|San Sebastian]] [[ayuntamiento]] in 1893;<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, p. 123</ref> the same coalition produced the same outcome in 1895, this time Olazábal elected as [[Councillor|concejal]].<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery'', see also ''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.05.95 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000180722&page=2 here]</ref> He made himself renowned for defending traditional local establishments against the centralising and modernising designs of the Madrid government. In 1896 he was forced to resign after a failed attempt to block ministerial legislation he considered detrimental to the interests of the city, but was reinstated following a successful appeal and served until 1899.<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref>
==''La Constancia''== [[File:Portada de La Constancia, 1 de julio de 1903.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|''La Constancia'', 1903]] In the late 1890s the Gipuzkoan Integrism underwent a major crisis, though its nature remains disputed. One theory highlights the alliance strategy; Nocedal changed his recommendations, suggesting coalitions with parties offering the best deal instead of the most approximate ones. Another theory attributes the conflict to nationalist penchant of the dissenters.<ref>see ''Integrismo'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/68615/50253 here]</ref> As they refused to step in line, the rebels, headed by [[Pedro Grijalba]], [[Ignacio Lardizábal]] and [[Aniceto de Rezola]], were expulsed by the provincial Junta.<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 122-127</ref> Since the outcasts<ref>the rebellious group, named Fueristas, tried to consolidate their position on the platform of regionalism and falling short of embracing Basque nationalism. It eventually disintegrated in 1898-1899, Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 122-127</ref> controlled a provincial Gipuzkoan Integrist daily ''El Fuerista'',<ref>few years earlier, during the crisis within Navarrese Integrism related to the stance taken by Arturo Campion, ''El Fuerista'' remained firmly in line with the party and lambasted the dissenters, see María Obieta Vilallonga, ''La escisión del «Tradicionalista» de Pamplona del seno del Partido Integrista(1893): la actitud de «El Fuerista» de San Sebastián'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 49 (1988), pp. 307-316</ref> Olazábal was asked to compensate for the loss; in 1897 he set up a new party newspaper, the San Sebastian-based ''[[:es:La Constancia (1897-1936)|La Constancia]]''; initially it appeared with a sub-title ''Diario Integro Fuerista'', later changed to ''Diario Integrista'',<ref>since August 1921</ref> ''Diario Integro-Tradicionalista''<ref>since September 1930</ref> and finally, ''Diario Tradicionalista''.<ref>since June 1932</ref> His personal property,<ref>Eduardo González Calleja, ''La prensa carlista y falangista durante la Segunda República y la Guerra Civil (1931-1937)'', [in:] ''El Argonauta español'' 9 (2012), available [http://argonauta.revues.org/819 here], also Antonio Checa Godoy, ''Prensa y partidos políticos durante la II República'', Salamanca 1989, {{ISBN|8474815215}}, 9788474815214, p. 281</ref> it was published until 1936 and, apart from being an official paper of Gipuzkoan Integrism for 34 years,<ref>until 1932, when Integrism amalgamated within mainstream Carlism</ref> until the end it remained sort of Olazábal’s personal political and ideological tribune.<ref>digital ''La Constancia'' archive for 1900-1936 is available [http://liburutegidigitala.donostiakultura.com/Liburutegiak/catalogo_archivo.php?dp_id=113 here]</ref>
Named after a Nocedalist daily of 1867-68,<ref>Germán Bleiberg, Maureen Ihrie, Janet Pérez, ''Dictionary of the Literature of the Iberian Peninsula'', vol. 2, Westport-London 1993, {{ISBN|0313287325}}, 9780313287329, p. 1166</ref> ''La Constancia'' was one of 4 dailies published in Gipuzkoa<ref>along ''La Voz de Guipúzcoa'' (republican), ''El Pueblo Vasco'' (monarchical), and ''El Día'' (autonomist), Arantxa Arzamendi Sese, ''Introducción a la prensa guipuzcoana: desde sus orígenes hasta 1936'', [in:] ''I Seminario sobre Patrimonio Bibliográfico Vasco'', Vitoria-Gasteiz 2005, {{ISBN|8445723154}}, p. 284</ref> and one of 14 periodicals controlled by the Integrists in Spain.<ref>or at least claimed so, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 11.06.07, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000267394&page=1 here]</ref> It remained a modest enterprise, with 2 journalists and 3 permanent collaborators.<ref>Félix Luengo Teixidor, ''La prensa guipuzcoana en los años finales de la Restauración (1917-1923)'', [in:] ''Historia contemporánea'' 2 (1989), p. 232, available [http://revista-hc.com/includes/pdf/02_13.pdf here]</ref> Its [[Newspaper circulation|circulation]] remained unimpressive; in 1920 it was 1,650 copies,<ref>most of them going to subscribers, presumably lower parochial clergy, Luengo Teixidor 1989, p. 232</ref> compared to 12,000 of the leading Gipuzkoan dailies, ''La Voz de Gipuzkoa'' and ''El Pueblo Vasco'',<ref>Miguel Artola, ''Historia de Donostia-San Sebastián'', Donostia 2000, {{ISBN|8489569495}}, 9788489569492, p. 534</ref> though still above this of an Integrist daily from neighboring Navarre, which went out of print in some 850-1000 copies.<ref>see Carlos Barrera del Barrio, ''La prensa navarra a través de las estadísticas oficiales (1867-1927)'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p. 48</ref> Given a semi-private nature of the paper, there is little doubt its longevity was sustained financially by industrial tycoons<ref>from [[List of regions in Gipuzkoa|Vale de Urola]], Luengo Teixidor 1989, p. 232-3</ref> of Integrist sympathies. Over the years it gradually became an icon of Traditionalist Spanish press.<ref>the daily is described as "uno de los decanos de la prensa tradicionalista", José Luis Orella, ''Cristina Barreiro Gordillo, El carlismo y su red de prensa en la Segunda República'', [in:] Arbil 79 (2004), available [http://www.arbil.org/%2879%29carl.htm here]</ref> ''La Constancia'' combined traditionalist Catholic ultraconservatism launched as Integrism by Nocedal with the defence of local Gipuzkoan identity and loyalty. During the Republican years it was subject to suspensions and other administrative measures.<ref>its first closure came in August 1931, 4 months after proclamation of the Republic, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.08.31 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000489661&page=1 here], see also Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, p. 62</ref> In the early 1930s it was integrated into the modern Carlist propaganda machinery and Olazabal ceded its directorship to [[Francisco Juaristi]]:;<ref>see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.04.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000539701&page=3 here]</ref> since 1934 it included one page in Basque.<ref>see ''La Constancia'' entry at [http://liburutegidigitala.donostiakultura.com/Liburutegiak/catalogo_ficha.php?dp_id=113 digital San Sebastian library site]</ref> After the outbreak of the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] its premises were seized by the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republican]] militias. Once the Carlists conquered San Sebastian its [[linotype machine]]s were used to launch ''La Voz de Espańa'', which employed also some of the ''La Constancia's'' editorial staff.<ref>dates differ,some claim ''La Voz'' was launched on September 16, José Andrés Gallego, Antón M. Pazos, ''Archivo Gomá: Abril-junio de 1938'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|8400084608}}, 9788400084608, p. 36, some claim it was September 15, see González Calleja 2012. At that time, Olazábal was kept prisoner in Bilbao</ref>
==Deputy== [[File:Donosti Députation Forale.jpg|thumbnail|Diputacion Foral building]] In the last years of the 19th century venomous hostility between Integrists and mainstream Carlists gave way to rapprochement,<ref>Jose María Remirez de Ganuza López, ''Las Elecciones Generales de 1898 y 1899 en Navarra'', [in] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 49 (1988), pp. 384</ref> commenced in Gipuzkoa. Its result was a provincial electoral alliance. In [[Azpeitia]], where two branches of Traditionalism used to compete, the Carlist candidate [[Teodoro Arana Belaustegui]] was withdrawn<ref>''Teodoro Arana Belaustegui'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/2173 here]; during the [[Spanish general election, 1899|1899 elections]] the Carlists, considering another insurgency, did not field official candidates, though individual candidates were allowed ("no habrá diputados carlistas en las próximas elecciones, pero podrá haber carlistas diputados"), Remirez 1988, p. 382, see also Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 189-191</ref> in favour of the Integrists. Their candidate turned out to be Olazábal,<ref>initially the Integrist candidate was [[Joaquin Pavia]], replaced shortly before the elections for unknown reasons, see Real Cuesta 1985, p. 191, also ''El Siglo Futuro'' 18.04.99 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000206664&page=1 here]</ref> elected also by Carlist votes<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 360; mainstream Carlists claimed that victorious Olazábal was their candidate, which, given the alliance concluded, was formally correct, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 18.04.99</ref> to the Cortes.<ref>see ''Olazabal y Ramery, Juan'' entry at ''Indice Historico de Diputados'' official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2881670%29.NDIP. here]</ref> The years of 1899-1901 were his only term in the parliament; during the successive elections the Azpeitia mandate – virtually ensured for the party – was claimed by other Integrist politicians.
For reasons which remain rather unclear<ref>none of the sources consulted offers any information as to why Olazábal did not prolong his parliamentary career; it appears to be his choice and not the result of electoral defeats, as neither scholarly works nor contemporary press mentions Olazábal running for the Cortes after 1901</ref> in the early 20th century Olazábal abandoned national politics and dedicated himself to the local Gipuzkoan issues. In 1904-1906 he engaged in a broad coalition<ref>including the Liberals, Conservatives, Integrists, mainstream Carlists and Republicans, but excluding the Nationalists and Socialists, Javier G. Chamorro, ''El Grande Oriente. Episodio Nacional, Madrid, 1821'', Donostia 2009, {{ISBN|8461323955}}, 9788461323951, p. 207</ref> named [[Liga Foral Autonomista de Guipúzcoa]] and became its second vicepresident.<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> The alliance declared itself dedicated to traditional provincial [[fueros]] and identified fiscal and administrative autonomy as its goals.<ref>see its program at ''gipuzkoa.net'' service available [http://w390w.gipuzkoa.net/WAS/CORP/DBKVisorBibliotecaWEB/visor.do?ver&amicus=178878&amicusArt=321573 here]</ref> Its immediate objective was negotiating a new [[Concierto económico]] with Madrid and indeed, a contemporary scholar considers the grouping simply a vehicle for pursuing economic goals of local industry tycoons.<ref>Chamorro 2009, p. 207; for detailed account see Luis Castells, ''Fueros y conciertos económicos. La Liga Foral Autonomista de Gipúzcoa(1904-1906)'', San Sebastián, 1980, {{ISBN|978-8474070774}}</ref>
Broad and loose political rapprochement of Gipuzkoan parties pursuing regionalist<ref>i.e. Gipuzkoan, not those covering [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]] or the broader Vasco-Navarrese region</ref> goals produced Olazábal’s success in elections to [[:es:Diputación Foral de Guipúzcoa|Diputación Provincial]]<ref>consisting of 12 members,4 from each of 3 districts: Irun, Tolosa and Sebastian, Antonio Cillán Apalategui, ''Elecciones a diputados provinciales en Guipuzcoa el año 1911'', [in:] ''Historia'' 22 (1977), p. 127, available [http://www.memoriadigitalvasca.es/bitstream/10357/6642/1/na%20276562001.pdf here]</ref> in 1907<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> and 1911,<ref>Cillán Apalategui 1977, p. 123, also Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> in 1914 serving as member of its [[Comisión Provincial]].<ref>''Guia Oficial de España'' 1914, p. 622, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001011466&page=612 here]</ref> He is noted not only for work promoting traditional local legal establishments,<ref>see numerous references to Olazabal's activity on autonomy in Idioia Estornés Zubizarreta, ''La construction de una nacionalidad Vasca. El Autonomismo de Eusko-Ikaskuntza (1918-1931)'', Donostia 1990, {{ISBN|8487471048}}, 9788487471049, available [http://www.euskomedia.org/PDFAnlt/vasconia/vas14/14015728.pdf here]</ref> but also for efforts to sustain typical Gipuzkoan agriculture, like protecting Pyrenaic cattle breeds by means of introducing [[herdbook]]s,<ref>Pedro Berriochoa Azcárate, ''Un centenario: Ignacio Camarero-Nuñez Arizmendi (1881-1910)'', [in:] ''Boletin de estudios historicos sobre San Sebastian'' 43 (2010), p. 142; relations with the Carlists remained good, see José Luis Orella Martínez, ''El origen del primer catolicismo social español'' [PhD thesis at Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Madrid 2012, pp. 101, 102, 114</ref> supporting the [[Fraisoro (agrarian school in Gipuzkoa)|Fraisoro]] agronomy school and supervising provincial veterinary services.<ref>Pedro Berriochoa Azcárate, ''1911: Incompatibilidades burocráticas sobre fondo caciquil en la Diputación de Gipuzkoa'', [in:] ''Historia Contemporánea'' 40 (2010), pp. 29-65</ref> Though lacking technical knowledge and somewhat incapacitated by a framework of political alliances, he nevertheless tried to promote the experts against incompetence of the politicians.<ref>"se defiende la postura del diputado Juan Olazábal (que era la de Olalquiaga) a través de sus intervenciones en el Consejo de diputados", quoted after Berriochoa Azcárate 2010, pp. 57</ref>
==''Jefe''== [[File:Amara Errondotik urumea.jpg|thumbnail|left|San Sebastian, early 20th century]] In the early 20th century Olazábal emerged as one of key Integrist politicians.<ref>along [[José Sánchez Marco|José Sanchez Marco]], Juan Antonio Sanchez del Campo, Juan Lamamie de Clairac and Manuel Senante</ref> His position was ensured as since the death of [[Ramón Zavala Salazar]] in 1899<ref>see ''Ramón Miguel María Julián Severino de Zavala y Salazar'' entry at ''Geni'' service, available [http://www.geni.com/people/Ram%C3%B3n-de-Zavala-y-Salazar/6000000020882273881 here]</ref> he was heading the party in its national stronghold.<ref>some claim that it was Olazábal who built the party strength in Gipuzkoa after the death of Nocedal, see Ignacio Arana Pérez, ''Historia contemporánea del Pais Vasco'', section 4.45.5. ''La lucha por la autonomia'', Leioa 2008, p. 4, available [http://www.celing.net/ingenieria/=/c1220080425.pdf here]. The issue of Gipuzkoan leadership is not entirely clear; the 1906 organigram of the provincial party structures names Olazábal merely as secretary of the local San Sebastian junta and president of the local Irun junta, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.05.06, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000259954&page=1 here]</ref> Following the death of Ramón Nocedal early 1907, leadership of the Integrist organization, [[:es:Partido Católico Nacional|Partido Católico Nacional]], was assumed by a triuumvirate,<ref>José Sanchez Marco, Benito de Guinea and Juan Olazábal, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 11.04.07 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000266299&page=1 here]; Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery'' claims the triuumvirate consisted of Juan de Olazábal, José Sánchez Marco y Manuel Aznar</ref> though few months later Olazábal became Presidente del Consejo.<ref>apart from leadership of the Gipuzkoan branch, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 11.06.07, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000267394&page=1 here]</ref> In 1909<ref>During Asamblea de Zaragoza</ref> he was elected the official party leader,<ref>Estornés Zubizarreta 1990, p. 220</ref> also nominated honorary president of a number of local Integrist juntas.<ref>like those in Navarre, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.07.09, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000282878&page=2 here], in Andalusia, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 26.07.12, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000306464&page=1 here] or in Murcia, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.01.13, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000310126&page=1 here]</ref>
Olazábal's leadership style was rather unobtrusive. Residing in San Sebastian he was away from great national politics; he did not compete for the Cortes and it was minority parliamentarian speaker, [[Manuel Senante Martinez|Manuel Senante]], acting as party representative in Madrid. Though formally the owner of national Integrist daily, ''[[El Siglo Futuro]]'',<ref>González Calleja 2012</ref> he left Senante to manage the newspaper and seldom contributed as an author, concentrating rather on ''La Constancia''. Finally, during political negotiations with other parties, he authorised the others to represent Partido Católico Nacional.<ref>e.g. during the 1914 talks on forging a broad Catholic alliance with the conservatives and the Jaimistas it was Senante representing Integrismo, Cristóbal Roblez Muñoz, ''Jesuitas e Iglesia Vasca. Los católicos y el partido conservador (1911-1913)'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' (1991), p. 224</ref>
In terms of political course Olazábal followed Nocedal closely. The fundamental assumption was that all public activity should be guided by Catholic principles and executed in line with the Roman Catholic teaching. In day-to-day activities it boiled down to opposing [[secularisation]] and defending the Church, as demonstrated during [[:es:Ley del candado|Ley de Candado]] crisis.<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> Secondary threads were promoting traditional regional establishments<ref>the party sided with the Catalanists in wake of the [[:es:Ley de Jurisdicciones|Ley de Jurisdicciones]] crisis , Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> and fighting democracy, especially parties combining nationalism and socialism.<ref>see Olazábal’s ''Errores nacionalistas y afirmacion Vasca'' (1919), available [http://atzoatzokoa.gipuzkoakultura.net/c34f2/index.php here]. Josep Carles Clemente, ''Historia del carlismo contemporaneo'', Barcelona 1977, p. 15 summarises Integrism as combination of 6 threads: adherence to French traditionalism (reason and natural law marginalised), manicheism, falsification of history, inquisitorial instincts, hostility to freedom of opinion, conservatist and capitalist ideology</ref> Towards the monarchy Integrism remained ambiguous, with some sections of the party favoring different dynastical visions<ref>it is not unrelated that during the [[First World War]] Olazábal joined [[Liga Neutralista]], a lobbying group acting in favour of the [[Central Powers]], considered closer to traditional model than the democratic [[Entente cordiale|Entente]], see Pedro Barruso Barés, ''San Sebastian en los siglos XIX y XX'', [in:] ''Geografia e historia de Donostia-San Sebastian'', available [http://www.ingeba.org/liburua/donostia/46contem/46contem.htm here]</ref> and some leaning towards accidentalism, prepared to accept a republican project.<ref>"Tres tendencias se van señalando entonces en el integrismo. Una, de acercamiento dinástico,generalmente de católicos procedentes de la aristocracia; otra, más señalada como antidinástica y tendentea pactar con los carlistas, pero sin refundirse con ellos, y una tercera, que partiendo de la accidentalidad delas formas de gobierno, aceptaría incluso una república del tipo de la de García Moreno en el Ecuador. Sin embargo,la unidad del partido integrista no se quebrantó, por la misma accidentalidad de las formas degobierno", [[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Melchor Ferrer]], Historia del tradicionalismo Español, vol. XVIII, Sevilla 1959, pp. 302-303</ref> [[File:Gregorio Cardinal aguirre.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Gregorio Maria Aguirre y Garcia|primate Aguirre]]]] Integrism, conceived by Nocedal as political arm of Spanish Catholicism,<ref>Ignacio Fernández Sarasola, ''Los partidos políticos en el pensamiento español: de la Ilustración a nuestros días'', Barcelona 2009, {{ISBN|8496467953}}, 9788496467958, p. 152</ref> has never gained more than lukewarm support of the bishops, alienated by its belligerent intransigence.<ref>Ferrer 1959, pp. 302-303</ref> During the Olazábal leadership things went from bad to worse, as the party was increasingly out of tune with the new Church policy. In the early 20th century the Spanish hierarchy abandoned its traditional strategy of influencing key individuals within the liberal monarchy,<ref>some scholars claim that the 19th century reluctance of the Church to sponsor its own Catholic political movement might have contributed to persistence of Integrism, see Feliciano Montero García, ''El movimiento católico en la España del siglo XX. Entre el integrismo y el posibilismo'', [in:] María Dolores de la Calle Velasco, Manuel Redero San Román (eds.), ''Movimientos sociales en la España del siglo XX'', Salamanca 2008, p. 178</ref> and switched to mass mobilisation<ref>the process was divided into 4 phases: 1) congresos catolicos of 1890-1903, 2) Lligas Católicas of 1903-1905, 3) malmenorismo of 1905-1910 and 4) targeted campaigns from 1910 onwards, see Rosa Ana Gutiérrez Lloret, ''¡A las urnas. En defensa de la Fe! La movilización política Católica en la España de comienzos del siglo XX'', [in:] ''Pasado y Memoria. Revista de Historia Contemporánea'' 7 (2008), pp. 240-241</ref> carried by means of broad<ref>in 1906 integrism was disqualified by the Spanish hierarchy as a political option; the church opted for possibilism, Montero Garcia 2008, p. 177</ref> popular structures and party politics.<ref>since Congreso de Burgos (1899) Leon XIII intended to create a common front of Catholic parties, co-ordinated by some sort of Junta central coordinadora and based on a program titled ''Bases y un programa común'', Montero Garcia 2008, p. 178, Gutiérrez Lloret 2008, p. 242</ref> The Integrists were reluctant to be one of many Catholic parties,<ref>though they participated in different Catholic alliances, for 1914 see Roblez Muñoz 1991, p. 224, for 1921 see Orella Martinez 2012, p. 238, also pp. 73, 80, 81</ref> despised the democratic format of policy-making<ref>Olazábal many times intervened with the primate and even in Vatican against what he perceived as promoting liberalism, see his actions against Gonzalo Coloma (brother of [[Luis Coloma|Padre Coloma]]) by Roblez Muñoz 1991, pp. 208-209, and in conflict with some bishops, see Cristóbal Robles, Cristóbal Robles Muñoz, ''José María de Urquijo e Ybarra: opinión, religión y poder'', Madrid 1997, {{ISBN|8400076680}}, 9788400076689, pp. 329. The Integrists straightforwardly condemned [[Grupo de la Democracia Cristiana]] (Maximiliano Arboleya Martíne, Severino Aznar) in 1919 and maintained anti-modernist stance, Montero Garcia 2008, p. 180</ref> and refused to accept "[[Lesser evil|malmenorismo]]".<ref>papal document ''Inter Catolicos Hispaniae'' advised accidentalism and the politics of lesser evil; it was followed by ''Las Normas para la acción social y política de los católicos españoles'', issued by the primate, Montero Garcia 2008, pp. 179-180; Gutiérrez Lloret 2008, pp. 249-250 presents the document as tailored to avoid divisions among Spanish Catholics, though its advocacy of malmenorismo was anyway rejected by Integrism</ref> Since Olazábal cultivated traditionalist vision of Catholic political engagement,<ref>confronted by the new christian-democratic strategy as reactionary and outdated, Montero Garcia 2008, pp. 244-5</ref> in 1910s and 1920s Partido Católico Nacional was dramatically outpaced by new breed of modern christian-democratic organizations.<ref>like [[:es:Asociación Católica Nacional de Propagandistas|Asociación Católica Nacional de Propagandistas]], [[Acción Catolica]], [[Confederación de Estiudantes Católicos]] or [[Juventud Católica Española]]; the new strategy initially fared badly in Gipuzkoa, where the Catholic Lligas were losing to Integrism, see Montero Garcia 2008, p. 247</ref>
Refusing to take part in [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|primoderiverista]] structures Olazábal focused on ''La Constancia'';<ref>publishing also separate booklets: ''Historia contemporánea: liquidando cuentas: cuestiones candentes que interesan a todos los vascos'' (1918), ''Errores nacionalistas y afirmación vasca'' (1919), ''El sufragio universal, el nacionalismo y los fueros'' (1919), ''En defensa del propietario rural guipuzcoano: colección de articulos'' (1930), ''Nuestro fuero y reyes de Castilla'' (1932); the most notable is, however, a 650-page ''El [[Manuel Santa Cruz Loidi|cura Santa Cruz]] guerillero'' (1928), intended as polemics with a competitive vision of the famour priest, presented by [[Pío Baroja]] in ''La Voz de Guipúzcoa''; see ''Catálogo del fondo histórico vasco'', Bilbao 2009, {{ISBN|8498308526}}, 9788498308525, p. 251, available [https://books.google.com/books?id=EG7vuC5AloIC&pg=PA251&dq=la+constancia+san+sebastian&hl=pl&sa=X&ei=ypyFVLb0B6fCywOQh4KADw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=la%20constancia%20san%20sebastian&f=false here]</ref> his 10-hectare<ref>Luisa Utanda Moreno, Francisco Feo Parrondo, ''Propiedad rústica en Guipúzcoa según el registro de la propiedad expropiable (1933)'', [in:] ''Lurralde: Investigación y espacio'', 18 (1995); the authors erroneously claim that [[Rafael Olazábal Eulate]] was Juan’s son</ref> Mundaiz estate<ref>where he lived together with his senile mother (she died in 1932 at the age of 90, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.04.32) and two sisters</ref> became an Integrist shrine.<ref>dubbed "alcázar del Integrismo", see Apalategui Igarzabal 2005, p. 57, or "Kremlin del Integrismo", see Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis], Valencia 2009, p. 319; in 1956 the Olazábal family sold part of the estate, enabling construction of a Catholic college, see [http://www.mundaiz.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=58&Itemid=87 here]; another part of the estate forms a Cristina Enea park, see [http://www.cristinaenea.org/pagina.php?queidioma=1&pg=9 here]</ref> Though Partido Católico Nacional was suspended, its offshoot organizations continued to function. Controlling them was getting increasingly difficult. In 1927 Olazábal expulsed the entire San Sebastian branch of [[Juventud Integrista]],<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 24.09.27, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000435509&page=1 here]</ref> a severe loss given its leader, [[:es:Ignacio María Echaide Lizasoain|Ignacio Maria Echaide]], launched the Juventud in 1910-1914.<ref>he left to pursue the independent politics of Basque Christian-Democracy, see ''euskonews'' service available [http://www.euskonews.com/0508zbk/efem50803es.html here], also ''euskaltzaindia'' available [http://www.euskaltzaindia.net/dok/euskera/50603.pdf here]</ref> In 1930 Integrism re-emerged as [[Comunión Tradicionalista-Integrista (Spanish party, 1930-1932)|Comunión Tradicionalista-Integrista]]. Still headed by Olazábal<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 11.04.30 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000469914&page=1 here]</ref> it maintained local branches in almost all Spanish provinces<ref>except [[Canary Islands]], see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 20.03.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000468968&page=1 here]</ref> and re-affirmed its traditional principles, though with little electoral success.<ref>in the last elections before advent of the Republic, the municipal vote of April 1931, the Integrists, apart from some success in the Vasco-Navarrese area, recorded few seats won also in Catalonia and Andalusia, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 42</ref>
==Republic and war== [[File:Almanac La Traca 1933.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|secular propaganda]] Militant [[Second Spanish Republic|republican]] secularism was acknowledged by the Integrists as a barbarian onslaught against the very foundations of civilisation.<ref>compare ''El Siglo Futuro'' 12.05.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000485608&page=1 here]</ref> Overwhelmed be the Leftist sway, Olazábal realized that his party stood little chance of surviving on its own.<ref>there were 3 Integrist politicians elected in the 1931 elections, but they were all running as “agrarian” candidates: Jose Lamamie de Clairac in Salamanca, Ricardo Gómez Roji and Francisco Estévanez Rodrigues in Burgos, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 57</ref> The row between traditionalist Integrism and modern [[christian-democratic]] groupings was already too wide and very few in the party considered rapprochement.<ref>there has never been any serious debate whether the Integrists should join any of the Catholic parties instead of Carlism, Montero Garcia 2008, pp. 186-190</ref> On the other hand, ultraconservative vision of religion was shared by mainstream Carlists; as a result, Integristas rather unanimously<ref>in some provinces of Spain it was even the Integros leading the way in the unification talks, Blinkhorn 1075, p. 73</ref> decided to swallow their accidentalism. Following 44 years of separate political existence Olazábal led them<ref>he was heading the reunification talks personally, see interview with Manuel Fal Conde by José Carlos Clemente, [in:] ''Tiempo de historia'' 39 (1978), pp. 13-23, referred after [http://elcaballerodeltristedestino.blogspot.com/2012_04_01_archive.html this site] </ref> to 1932<ref>Olazábal formally resigned as head of the Integrist party in February 1932, Manuel Ferrer Muñoz, ''Los frustrados intentos de colaboración entre el partido nacionalista vasco y la derecha navarra durante la segunda república'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p. 131</ref> reunification within Carlism, into the party named [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]].<ref>and dubbed "Guardia Civil de la Iglesia" by an unsympathetic historian, see Fermín Pérez-Nievas Borderas, ''Contra viento y marea'', Estella 1999, {{ISBN|8460589323}}, p. 97</ref>
Within consolidated Carlism the former Integrists remained a very influential group. By means of a new publishing house, [[Editorial Tradicionalista]], they continued to control ''El Siglo Futuro'', which became a semi-official Carlist daily.<ref>Editorial Tradicionalista was set up specifically to neutralize the Integrist influence, but the plan came to nothing as Senante and Lamamie dominated in the board. It was only its new composition, reconstituted in December 1933, which ensured closer amalgamation of ''El Siglo Futuro'' within the Carlist propaganda machinery, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 336</ref> Many former Integros, like a Cantabrian [[José Luis Zamanillo González-Camino|Jose Luis Zamanillo]], Castillano [[José María Lamamié de Clairac|José Lamamie]], Alicantino Manuel Senante or Andalusian [[Manuel Fal Conde|Manuel Fal]] assumed top positions within the party.<ref>Fal became the party leader, Zamanillo head of the Requete section, Lamamie presided over the Secretariat and Senante kept editing ''El Siglo Futuro''</ref> Olazábal, due to his age hardly involved in day-to-day business, became sort of a mentor and moral authority. The visible Integrist impact on Comunión Tradicionalista triggered some grumblings among Carlists, especially among the [[Navarre]]se.
Olazábal kept lambasting secular republicanism,<ref>he became notorious for explaining floods as God’s punishment, measured against peasants working on Sundays, see William A. Christian, ''Visionaries: The Spanish Republic and the Reign of Christ'', Berkeley 1996, {{ISBN|0520200403}}, 9780520200401, p. 361</ref> which cost ''El Siglo Futuro'' and ''La Constancia'' periodical administrative suspensions (the first one in August 1931) and Olazábal himself a police detention;<ref>Carlist press compared the republican detentions to fascist or soviet measures, see the "como Mussolini! como Lenin!" heading of ''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.08.31 [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000489661&page=1 here]</ref> he spent three days in jail.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 62</ref> Always championing local traditional establishments, he was profoundly disappointed by turn of the Basque cause.<ref>until 1932 Olazabal hoped that the Basques would return to the Integrist core, see ''Euskera: se empieza inventando un idioma''…</ref> He denounced the initial autonomy draft<ref>produced by the Academy of Basque Studies, Blinkhorn 1975, pp. 48-9</ref> as godless, considering also the [[:es:Estatuto Vasco-Navarro|Estella Statute]] version anti-religious<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> and anti-fuerist.<ref>he criticised the unitarian nature of autonomy, which he deemed to have been against traditional vision of separate provincial laws and institutions</ref> Within the united Carlist community he and [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Victor Pradera]] led the anti-statute group, as opposed to the pro-statute Carlists represented by [[José Luis de Oriol y Urigüen|José Luis Oriol]] and [[Marcelino Oreja Elósegui|Marcelino Oreja]].<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 82</ref> The divided Carlists refrained from taking a clear political stance, which eventually contributed to failure of the autonomy project.<ref>detailed analysis in Santiago de Pablo, ''El carlismo guipuzcoano y el Estatuto Vasco'', [in:] ''Bilduma Rentería'' 2 (1988), p. 193-216, available [http://www.errenteria.net/es/ficheros/40_9775es.pdf here]</ref> [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|Carlist standard]] It is not clear whether Olazábal was engaged in Carlist preparations to rebellion and whether he was even aware of the forthcoming insurgency.<ref>he is not named by any of the sources consulted, especially by the most detailed study, Juan Carlos Peñas Bernaldo de Quirós, ''El Carlismo, la República y la Guerra Civil (1936-1937). De la conspiración a la unificación'', Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|8487863523}}, 9788487863523</ref> Following the outbreak of hostilities he remained in San Sebastian, where the coup failed, and went on editing ''La Constancia''.<ref>Asarta Epenza, ''Juan de Olazábal Ramery''</ref> He was detained on one of the ships anchored in San Sebastian and later moved to the Bilbao Angeles Custodios prison. Since the Basque government did not deploy autonomous police to protect the building during the unrest,<ref>some sources claim there were no police units available, see José Manuel Azcona Pastor, Julen Lezamiz Lugarezaresti, ''Los asaltos a las cárceles de Bilbao el día 4 de enero de 1937'', [in:] ''Investigaciones históricas'' 32 (2012), pp. 230; some sources claim the Basque government refused to deploy police troops fearing outbreak of hostilities between UGT and PNV, see Jon Juaristi, ''Turbas'' [in:] ''El Imparcial'' 25.06.14, available [http://www.elimparcial.es/noticia/26327/nacional/turbas here]</ref> caused by the nationalist bombing raid over the city, the prison was entrusted to the [[Unión General de Trabajadores|UGT]] militia unit. On January 4 the socialist militiamen executed around 100 prisoners;<ref>full list in Azcona, Lezamiz 2012, pp. 235-6</ref> some were killed by hand grenades thrown into the cells, some were shot and some were reportedly slashed with machetes.<ref>Juaristi 2014</ref> It is not clear how exactly Juan Olazábal died.<ref>detailed accounts differ; Pedro Barruso Barés, ''La represión en las zonas republicana y franquista del País Vasco durante la Guerra Civil'', [in:] ''Historia Contemporánea'' 35 (2007), pp. 653-681 identifies the perpetrators as "incontrolados" militants of CNT and UGT, while the anarchists denied any responsibility, see their account ''La manipulación de la Memoria Histórica'', [in:] ''CNT Gipuzkoa'', available [http://gipuzkoa.cnt.es/spip.php?article388 here]</ref>
==See also== * [[Carlism]] * [[Integrism (Spain)]] * [[:es:La Constancia (1897-1936)|''La Constancia'']] * ''[[El Siglo Futuro]]'' * [[Ramón Nocedal Romea]] * [[Manuel Senante Martinez]]
==Footnotes== {{Reflist|3}}
==Further reading== * Cristina Barreiro Gordillo, ''El carlismo y su red de prensa en la Segunda República'', Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|8497390377}} * Pedro Berriochoa Azcárate, ''1911: Incompatibilidades burocráticas sobre fondo caciquil en la Diputación de Gipuzkoa''', [in:] ''Historia Contemporánea'' 40 (2010), pp. 29-65 * Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}} * Luis Castells, ''Fueros y conciertos económicos. La Liga Foral Autonomista de Gipúzcoa (1904-1906)''. San Sebastián, 1980, {{ISBN|978-8474070774}} * Antonio Cillán Apalategui, ''Elecciones a diputados provinciales en Guipuzcoa el año 1911'', [in:] ''Historia'' 22 (1977), pp. 121-127 * Idioia Estornés Zubizarreta, ''La construction de una nacionalidad Vasca. El Autonomismo de Eusko-Ikaskuntza (1918-1931)'', Donostia 1990 * María Obieta Vilallonga, ''Los integristas guipuzcoanos. Desarrollo y organización del Partido Católico Nacional en Guipúzcoa (1888-1898)'', Bilbao 1996, {{ISBN|8470863266}}, 9788470863264
==External links== [[File:Deusto mundaiz 0001.JPG|thumbnail|Mundaiz estate today]] * [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/116770 Juan Olazábal on euskomedia] * [https://es.wikisource.org/wiki/Estatuto_de_Estella Estella Statute text] * [http://irudi.gipuzkoa.net/WAS/CORP/DCMVisorBibliotecaWEB/Visualizar.do?amicus=178878&amicusArt=321573 Liga Foral declaration] * [http://www.elimparcial.es/nacional/turbas-26327.html death of Juan Olazabal] * [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2881670%29.NDIP. Historical Index of Deputies 1899] * [http://www.euskalnet.net/laviana/gen_bascas/olazabal.htm Olazábal family explained] * [http://www.cristinaenea.org/pagina.php?queidioma=1&pg=15 virtual visit at a former Olazábal Mundaiz estate] * [http://www.mundaiz.com/index.php Catholic college at former Olazábal Mundaiz estate] * {{citation |url=http://www.liburuklik.euskadi.net/applet/libros/JPG/diputacion/FSS_005746/FSS_005746.pdf |title=Historia contemporánea: liquidando cuentas: cuestiones candentes que interesan a todos los vascos |author= Olazábal |via=[[Liburuklik]] }} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vq3vWInEhcE Errekete (Euskara)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uhK1ER3B4Hg ''Vizcainos! Por Dios y por España''; contemporary Carlist propaganda]

page.title: List of amusement parks in Asia

This is a '''list of churches in [[Stockholm]], the capital of [[Sweden]]'''. The list does not include chapels or minor churches.
Churches in [[Stockholm County]] outside Stockholm municipality are listed in two separate lists: [[List of churches in Uppland]] and [[List of churches in Södermanland]].
Note: in the list, "Year" denotes the year construction of the church was finished, when it was inaugurated, or the main construction period of the church.

page.title: List of cities in the Baltic states by population

revision.text:
This is a list of cities in the [[Baltic states]] by population. The population is measured within city limits on a national level, independently, by each statistical bureau. They are: ''Latvijas Statistika'' ([[Latvia]]),<ref name="Latvian population">{{cite web|url=http://data.csb.gov.lv/Table.aspx?layout=tableViewLayout1&px_tableid=IS0120.px&px_path=Sociala__Ikgad%C4%93jie%20statistikas%20dati__Iedz%C4%ABvot%C4%81ji__Iedz%C4%ABvot%C4%81ji%20skaits%20un%20t%C4%81%20izmai%C5%86as&px_language=en&px_db=Sociala&rxid=fde7b5a9-c3e8-489e-bb08-5561a022a5b5 |title=Table ISG12. RESIDENT POPULATION BY STATISTICAL REGION, CITY AND COUNTY |publisher=csb.gov.lv |accessdate=22 June 2014}}</ref> ''Eesti Statistika'' ([[Estonia]]),<ref>[http://www.stat.ee/?lang=en Statistics Estonia]</ref> and ''Lietuvos Statistika'' ([[Lithuania]]).<ref>[http://osp.stat.gov.lt/web/guest/statistiniu-rodikliu-analize?portletFormName=visualization&hash=45df86a4-d8a0-4d6c-8998-18f2a3964b51 Lietuvos statistika]</ref> Of the top 30 cities by population in the Baltics, 15 are Lithuanian, 10 are Latvian, and 5 are Estonian.

{{update|inaccurate=y|date=February 2016}} {{more citations needed|date=February 2016}} {{Politics of Georgia (country)}} A '''municipality''' ({{lang-ka|მუნიციპალიტეტი}}, ''munits'ipaliteti'') is a subdivision of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], consisting of a settlement or a group of settlements, which enjoys [[Local government in Georgia (country)|local self-government]]. There are two types of municipalities—self-governing [[List of cities and towns in Georgia (country)|cities]] (ქალაქი, ''k'alak'i''), 12 in total, and self-governing [[Community (administrative division)|communities]] (თემი, temi), 67 in total.{{cite web|url=https://mreg.reestri.gov.ge/|title=Registry of Municipalities|publisher=National Agency of Public Registry|accessdate=January 23, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202020853/https://mreg.reestri.gov.ge/|archivedate=February 2, 2017|df=}} == Background == The municipalities were first established in 2006. Most of them were successors to the earlier subdivisions, known as ''[[raioni]]'' (რაიონი), "districts". In addition, new municipalities were formed to govern those settlements in the disputed entities of [[Abkhazia]] and [[South Ossetia]] that then remained under Georgia's control. After the [[Russo-Georgian War]] of 2008, Georgia treats these municipalities as parts of its [[Occupied territories (Georgia)|occupied territories]]. The former districts not under Georgia's effective sovereignty at the moment of the local government reform of 2006 were not transformed into municipalities. Rather, the laws of Georgia include a notion that the final mode of subdivision and system of local self-government should be established after the restoration of the state jurisdiction over the occupied territories.{{cite web|title=ტერიტორიული მოწყობა და მმართველობა [Territorial Structure and Government]|url=https://president.gov.ge/ge/Georgia/TerritorialStructureAndGovernment|publisher=Administration of the President of Georgia|accessdate=9 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710064058/https://president.gov.ge/ge/Georgia/TerritorialStructureAndGovernment|archivedate=10 July 2015|df=}}{{cite act |title=ადგილობრივი თვითმმართველობის კოდექსი [Code of Local Self-Government] |type=Organic law |number=1958-IIს |language=Georgian |date=5 February 2014 |article= |articletype= |url=https://matsne.gov.ge/ka/document/view/2244429 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} In 2014, the system of local government was further reformed and a total number of municipalities were increased at the expense of adding more self-governing cities. Each municipality is divided into administrative units (ადმინისტრაციული ერთეული), which can comprise one or several settlements.{{cite web|title=Transparency remains a challenge for self-governing cities|url=http://transparency.ge/en/node/4777|publisher=Transarency International Georgia|accessdate=9 July 2015|date=28 October 2014}} The municipalities outside the two [[autonomous republic]]s of [[Adjara]] and of [[Abkhazia]] and the capital city of [[Tbilisi]] are grouped, on a provisional basis, into nine regions (''[[mkhare]]''): [[Guria]], [[Imereti]], [[Kakheti]], [[Kvemo Kartli]], [[Mtskheta-Mtianeti]], [[Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti]], [[Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti]], [[Samtskhe-Javakheti]], and [[Shida Kartli]]. == Alphabetical list of municipalities == {| class="center" | {{Image label begin|image=Georgian municipalities with higlightened regions - coloured (updated).svg{{!}}link=|font-size=85%|width=850|float=}} {{Image label small|x=0.426|y=0.152|scale=1300|text=[[Kazbegi Municipality|Kazbegi]]}} {{Image label small|x=0.412|y=0.21|scale=1300|text=[[Akhalgori Municipality|Akhalgori]]}} {{Image label small|x=0.431|y=0.256|scale=1300|text=[[Mtskheta Municipality|Mtskheta]]}} {{Image label small|x=0.445|y=0.245|scale=1300|text=[[Mtskheta|''c.
