page.title: List of programmes broadcast by CITV

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/37.203.49.2|37.203.49.2]] ([[User talk:37.203.49.2|talk]]) to last version by IanDBeacon
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} The following is a list of programming, past and present, which has been carried by [[CITV]], the [[children's television series|children's television]] strand of [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] in the United Kingdom, both in the form of the programming block carried from 3 January 1983 to 2007, and on the separate CITV digital channel since 11 March 2006. More details about both the past programming block and current channel are contained within the CITV article.
==Current programming==
===Original=== ====Animated==== * ''[[Grizzly Tales for Gruesome Kids]]'' * ''[[Horrid Henry (TV series)|Horrid Henry]]'' * ''[[Mr. Bean (animated TV series)|Mr. Bean: The Animated Series]]'' * ''Oddbods'' * ''Robozuna'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/10/netflix-add-six-new-kids-series-super-monsters-avi-arad-1201831667/|title=Netflix Orders Six New Kids Series Including ‘Lego Elves’ & Avi Arad’s ‘Super Monsters’|first=Denise|last=Petski|date=6 October 2016|website=deadline.com|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> * ''[[CITV#Share a Story|Share a Story]]'' * ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go (TV series)|Thunderbirds Are Go]]'' * ''[[Wolves, Witches and Giants]]''
====Live-action==== * ''[[Bear Grylls#Bear Grylls' Survival School|Bear Grylls' Survival School]]'' * ''Bottom Knocker Street'' * ''[[Fort Boyard: Ultimate Challenge]]'' * ''[[Horrible Science#TV series|Horrible Science]]'' * ''[[My Parents Are Aliens]]'' * ''[[My Phone Genie]]'' * ''[[Scrambled!]]'' * ''[[Sooty (2011 TV series)|Sooty]]'' * ''Spy School''
====Upcoming==== * ''[[Mr. Magoo]]'' (Spring 2019)<ref>http://www.televisionpost.com/xilams-2d-animation-series-of-mr-magoo-to-be-aired-on-citv/</ref> * ''Bear Grylls Young Adventurer'' (2019)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toonbarn.com/other-cartoons/bear-grylls-young-adventurer-ready-explore-2019/|website=ToonBarn|accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref> * ''The Rubbish World of Dave Spud'' (Summer 2019)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kidscreen.com/2017/10/06/citv-commissions-new-series-from-ifc/|title=CITV commissions new series from IFC|website=kidscreen.com|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> * ''Freak Street'' (1 September 2018)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=1264225997014522&id=219216124848853|title=UK kidsnet CITV has picked up Kindle Entertainment animated series Freak Street from London-based distributor UK Steel. The 52 x 11-minute animated series is produced by the Britain, London-based studio (Fleabag Monkeyface, Captain Fact, Zac Zolton) and was originally commissioned by Corus Entertainment for its UK and English Teletoon feeds, where it premiered in September 2018.|website=facebook.com|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref>
===Acquired=== ====Animated==== * ''[[Adventure Time]]'' * ''[[Ben 10 (2016 TV series)|Ben 10]]'' * ''[[Lego Ninjago: Masters of Spinjitzu]]'' * ''[[Mighty Magiswords]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.regularcapital.com/2018/04/mighty-magiswords-to-air-on-uk-free-to-air-childrens-channel-citv/}}</ref> * ''[[The Powerpuff Girls (2016 TV series)|The Powerpuff Girls]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/tv-programme/e/ffpzx7/the-powerpuff-girls--07112016|title=The Powerpuff Girls - 07/11/2016|website=Radio Times|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> * ''[[Teen Titans Go! (TV series)|Teen Titans Go!]]'' * ''[[Transformers: Robots in Disguise (2015 TV series)|Transformers: Robots in Disguise]]'' * ''[[Be Cool, Scooby-Doo!]]'' * ''[[Scooby-Doo! Mystery Incorporated]]'' * ''[[The Tom and Jerry Show (2014 TV series)|The Tom and Jerry Show]]'' * ''[[What's New, Scooby-Doo?]]'' * ''[[Avengers Assemble (TV series)|Avengers Assemble]]''<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/hub/marvels-avengers-assemble/2a4084a0027# |title=Archived copy |access-date=14 November 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161115132345/http://www.itv.com/hub/marvels-avengers-assemble/2a4084a0027# |archive-date=15 November 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * ''[[Lego Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures]]'' * ''[[Max Steel (2013 TV series)|Max Steel]]'' * ''[[Ultimate Spider-Man]]''<ref>http://presscentre.itvstatic.com/presscentre/sites/presscentre/files/itv_week_03_highlights_2017.pdf</ref> * ''[[Fangbone!]]'' * ''[[Super 4 (TV series)|Super 4]]'' * ''[[The Bagel and Becky Show]]'' * ''[[Looped (TV series)|Looped]]'' * ''[[Mysticons]]'' * ''[[Matt Hatter Chronicles]]'' * ''[[ToonMarty]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tbivision.com/news/2017/08/citv-picks-toonmarty/782352/|title=CITV picks up ToonMarty - TBI Vision - Page 782352|website=tbivision.com|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> * ''[[Wishfart]]'' * ''[[Almost Naked Animals]]'' * ''[[Nerds and Monsters]]'' * ''[[Om Nom Stories]]'' * ''[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=Pokemon|url=https://www.itv.com/hub/pokemon/|website=itv.com|accessdate=7 November 2017|language=en}}</ref>

Super Show!]]'' * ''[[Dino Dan]]'' * ''[[Dino Dan#Season 2 - Trek's Adventures|Dino Dan: Trek's Adventures]]'' * ''The Avatars'' * ''[[K.C. Undercover]]'' <ref>https://www.radiotimes.com/tv/tv-listings/?sd=16-07-2018%2017:00]|date=July 2018</ref> * [[Mech-X4]] * ''[[Ben 10 Ultimate Challenge|Ben 10 Challenge]]''
==Signed Stories== Signed Stories was created by ITV SignPost – ITV’s centre of excellence for multi-platform British Sign Language services – as a resource for deaf children and their families, and for teachers of deaf children. The £1.5million initiative was delivered with some of the world’s leading publishers, as part of the company’s corporate and social responsibility plan to give deaf children access to the best children’s books in their native sign language.
The free website www.signedstories.com has grown in popularity with deaf and hearing children, children with special educational needs and those learning English as a second language – it’s now used by hundreds of thousands of children around the world, at school and in the home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signedstories.com|title=Welcome to Signed Stories|website=www.signedstories.com|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} [[File:Amsterdam red light district 24-7-2003.JPG|thumb|upright=1.3|[[De Wallen]] red-light district in [[Amsterdam]]]] '''Red-light districts''' are areas associated with the [[sex industry]] and sex-oriented businesses (e.g. [[sex shop]]s and [[strip club]]s). In some of these places [[prostitution]] may legally take place. Other [[red-light district]]s are known for their illegal prostitution scene (in countries where prostitution is illegal). In red light districts where prostitution is illegal prostitutes or clients may be arrested or fined if caught by the police (the enforcement of anti-prostitution laws varies by country or place). Following is a partial list of well known red-light districts around the world, both current and historical.
__TOC__

page.title: List of wars involving the People's Republic of China

revision.text:
{{See also|List of Chinese wars and battles|List of wars involving the Republic of China}} This is a '''list of wars involving the [[People's Republic of China]]'''. == Wars == :{{legend2|#AFA|Chinese military victory|border=1px solid #AAA}} :{{legend2|#F88|Chinese military defeat|border=1px solid #AAA}} :{{legend2|#ACF|Indecisive or unclear outcome|border=1px solid #AAA}} :{{legend2||Ongoing conflict|border=1px solid #AAA}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="background:#E23D28; width:200px;"|War ! style="background:#E23D28; width:160px;"|People's Republic of China and allies ! style="background:#E23D28; width:160px;"|Opponents ! style="background:#E23D28; width:300px;"|Result |- |style="background:#efefef"| [[Chinese Civil War]]
(1927–1950){{efn|Although main fighting ceased in 1950, warfare with the [[Republic of China]] continued throughout the 1950s and 1960s with the * [[Kuomintang Islamic insurgency in China (1950–58)|Kuomintang Islamic insurgency in China]] (1950–1958) * [[First Taiwan Strait Crisis]] (1954–1955) * [[Second Taiwan Strait Crisis]] (1958) * [[1960–61 campaign at the China–Burma border|Campaign at the China–Burma Border]] (1960–1961) }} |style="background:#efefef"| {{flagicon image|Flag of the Chinese Communist Party (Pre-1996).svg|size=22px}} [[Communist Party of China|Communist Party]] |style="background:#efefef"| {{flagicon image|Flag of the Republic of China.svg|size=22px}} [[Nationalist Government|Nationalist China]] *{{flagicon image|Naval Jack of the Republic of China.svg|size=22px}} [[Kuomintang]] *[[File:Republic of China Army Flag.svg|22px|border]] [[National Revolutionary Army|NRA]] |style="background:#AFA"| '''Victory''' (to the Communist Party) *Formation of the [[People's Republic of China]]. *Nationalist government relocated to Taiwan. |- |style="background:#efefef"| [[Battle of Chamdo]]

{{for|the Aragonese comarca|Maestrazgo, Aragon}} {{Infobox settlement | name = ''Maestrazgo'' / ''Maestrat'' | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- ISO 639-2 code e.g. "fr" for French. If more than one, use {{lang}} instead --> | settlement_type = [[Natural region]] | image_skyline = Penyagolosa pic1.JPG | image_alt = | image_caption = Landscape in the area of the summit of = | population_note = | timezone1 = | utc_offset1 = | timezone1_DST = | utc_offset1_DST = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | footnotes = }} The '''Maestrazgo''' ({{IPA-es|maesˈtɾaðɣo|lang}}) or '''Maestrat''' ({{IPA-ca|maesˈtɾat|langva}}) is a [[natural region|natural]] and [[historical region|historical]] [[mountainous]] region, located at the eastern end of the [[Sistema Ibérico]] mountain range, in [[Spain]]. It encompasses the north of the [[Autonomous communities of Spain|Autonomous Community]] of [[Valencian Community|Valencia]], in [[Castellón (province)|Castellón]] province, and parts of the east of the [[Aragon]]ese province of [[Teruel (province)|Teruel]]. The area is mountainous and sparsely populated with a rich mixture of flora and fauna.
The district was under control of [[Military order (society)|military order]]s following the 12th-century Christian reconquest of the area from the [[Moors]]. It also had a significant role in the 19th century [[Carlist Wars]] and the 20th century [[Spanish Civil War]]. After many years of decline the area is undergoing some re-vitalization, helped by funding from the [[European Union]] and tourism.
==History== [[File:Valltorta Albocàsser.jpg|right|thumb|Cave painting at la Valltorta ravine.]] The earliest signs of human habitation date back to the [[Pleistocene]] era, 25,000 years ago. Cave paintings have been discovered in many locations and they have been designated by [[UNESCO]] as part of the [[Rock Art of the Mediterranean Basin on the Iberian Peninsula]] [[World Heritage Site]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/874/multiple=1&unique_number=1026 |title=Rock Art of the Mediterranean Basin on the Iberian Peninsula |publisher= UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=2009-11-16 }} </ref>
Occupation by the [[Ilercavones]], a tribe of [[Iberians]], [[Ancient Rome#Empire|Roman]]s and the [[Moors]] followed, but the identity of the region was first established following the [[Reconquista]] when the area was dominated by [[Military order (society)|military order]]s. Local stories persist that a group of [[Catharism|Cathars]], led by the [[Cathar Perfect|perfectus]] [[Guillaume Bélibaste]] escaped from Carcassonne and took refuge in the Maestrazgo, living with a small community near [[Morella, Castellon|Morella]] for about ten years, before being betrayed by a spy in the service of the [[Medieval Inquisition|Inquisition]]. Bélibaste was taken to [[Carcassonne]] and burnt at the stake there.<ref name="webster01">Webster, 198-202</ref>
The name Maestrazgo is derived from the word ''maestre'' (English meaning - master) as these territories were historically under the jurisdiction of the [[Grand Master (order)|Grand Masters]] of the military orders of the [[Knights Templar]], [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta|St John of Malta]] and [[Order of Montesa|Montesa]].<ref name=mancomunidad-turisto> {{cite web |url=http://www.elmaestrazgo.com/eng/conozcanos.htm |title=Mancomunidad Turística del Maestrazgo |publisher=www.elmaestrazgo.com |accessdate=2009-11-16 }} </ref>
In 1838, during the [[Carlist Wars]], the military district of ''la Comandancia General del Maestrazgo'' was created by [[Ramón Cabrera y Griñó|Ramón Cabrera]].<ref name=mancomunidad-turisto/> During the [[Spanish Civil War]] the area was intensively fought over, especially after the [[Battle of Teruel|fall of Teruel]]. [[Spanish Maquis|Republican guerillas]] of the ''Agrupación guerrillera de Levante y Aragón'' held out in the mountains of the Maestrazgo until the 1950s.<ref name="webster02">Webster, 162-164</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.morella.net/morella/conocenos/historia_de_morella/historia_contemporanea |title=Coneix la història de Morella: prehistòria, medieval, moderna i contemporània |publisher=La ciutat de Morella |format=Valenciano |accessdate=2009-11-17 }} </ref>
==Geography== The mountains in the Maestrazgo, like the [[Serra de la Creu, Maestrat|Serra de la Creu]], [[Serra d'En Segures]], [[Talaies d'Alcalà]], [[Serra de la Vall d'Àngel]], [[Serra d'en Galceran]], [[Serra d'Esparreguera]], [[Serra de Sant Pere]], [[Serra de Vallivana]], [[Serra d'En Celler]], [[Tossal de la Barbuda]], [[Montegordo]], the [[Cervera Mountains]], [[Serra del Turmell]], [[Serra de l'Espadella]], [[Moles de Xert]] and the [[Benifassà Mountains]], form the Mediterranean end of the [[Sistema Ibérico]]. The highest point is the {{convert|1831|m|ft}} high [[Penyagolosa]], located at the southern end of the region. At the base of the mountain is the important pilgrimage destination of Sant Joan de Penyagolosa.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.amarguillo.com/maestre/penya_golosa22.html |title=Rutas de montaña, álbum Peña Golosa |format=Spanish |publisher=www.amarguillo.com |accessdate=2009-11-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312091529/http://www.amarguillo.com/maestre/penya_golosa22.html |archivedate=2009-03-12 |df= }} </ref>
In the Castellón province administrative divisions, the Maestrazgo is divided into [[Alt Maestrat]] and [[Baix Maestrat]]. The historical territory does not exactly match these boundaries including also parts of [[Alcalatén]] and [[Plana Alta]]. In [[Aragon]], [[Teruel Province]] there is a [[comarca]] officially called [[Maestrazgo, Aragon|Maestrazgo]] since 1999, but historically locations in other districts were also part of the Maestrazgo. The region has formed a Mancomunidad, a free association for cooperative purposes, between fifty five municipalities.<ref name=mancomunidad-turisto/> Major settlements include [[Vilafranca]], [[Cantavieja]], [[Morella, Castellon|Morella]] and [[Alcañiz]].
The Maestrazgo Cultural Park has been established to protect the regional culture and landscape. The area lies between altitudes of {{convert|480|m|ft}} to {{convert|1997|m|ft}} and is drained by the [[Guadalope]] and [[Turia (river)|Turia]] rivers.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.europeangeoparks.org/isite/page/66,1,0.asp |title=The Maestrazgo Cultural Park ( Spain) |publisher=European Geoparks Network |accessdate=2009-11-16 }} </ref>
==Flora and fauna== The Maestrazgo supports a diverse section of plants and trees including [[thyme]], [[rosemary]], [[lavender]], [[Lamiaceae|mint]], [[Mentha pulegium|pennyroyal]], [[Sideritis|mountain tea]], [[chamomile]], [[Truffle|black truffles]], [[Populus|poplar]]s, [[elm]]s, [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]], [[beech]], [[Quercus ilex|holm oak]]s and [[European black pine|black pine]].<ref name=mancomunidad-turisto/><ref name=webster03>Webster, 327-342</ref>
Fauna includes [[Spanish ibex|ibex]], [[Mouflon|muflón]], [[wildcat]]s, [[otter]]s, [[European pine marten|pine marten]]s, [[fox]]es, [[Common genet|genets]], [[Northern goshawk|goshawk]]s, [[Bonelli's eagle]]s, [[Eurasian sparrowhawk|sparrowhawk]]s, [[owl]]s, [[vulture]]s, and game and fish such as [[partridge]]s, [[quail]]s, [[hare]]s, [[rabbit]]s, [[wild boar]], [[trout]], and [[catfish]].<ref name=mancomunidad-turisto/>
==Today== Tourism has in recent years brought a halt to economic decline in the region and the injection of [[European Union]] funding has led to the development of heritage centres and cooperatives providing training in practical crafts.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/agriculture/rur/leader2/rural-en/biblio/culture/art06.htm |title=Maestrazgo-Teruel: counting on identity to produce sustainable development|work=Leader Magazine|publisher=European Commission |date=Winter 1994 |accessdate=2009-11-16 }} </ref> Agriculture, including pigs, poultry, sheep, goats and smallholdings predominate in the valleys.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.elmaestrat.es/ |title=El maestrat,revista y excursiones |format=Spanish |publisher=www.elmaestrat.es |accessdate=2009-11-19 }} </ref> In 1995, [[Ken Loach]]'s award winning<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/3365/year/1995.html |title=Land and Freedom |publisher=Festival de Cannes |accessdate=2009-11-20 }}</ref> film about the Spanish Civil War, ''[[Land and Freedom]]'', was filmed in the Maestrazgo.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.filmeducation.org/pdf/film/LandFreedom.pdf |title=Land and Freedom: Teachers Notes |publisher=www.filmeducation.org |accessdate=2009-11-16 }} </ref> Life in the area and much of its history is described vividly in [[Jason Webster (author)|Jason Webster]]'s 2009 book '' Sacred Sierra - A Year on a Spanish Mountain''.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/reviews/sacred-sierra-by-jason-webster-1654794.html |title=Sacred Sierra, By Jason Webster|work=The Independent |date=27 March 2009 |publisher=Independent News and Media |accessdate=2009-11-16 |last=Evans |first=Julian }} </ref> Efforts have been made to halt de-population by attracting immigrants from [[South America]] and [[Romania]]. This has had some success, helping keeping village facilities alive.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/uk/nexis/results/docview/docview.do?docLinkInd=true&risb=21_T7903493418&format=GNBFI&sort=BOOLEAN&startDocNo=26&resultsUrlKey=29_T7903493421&cisb=22_T7903493420&treeMax=true&treeWidth=0&csi=8010&docNo=34 |title=Returnadores: a new life in the old world|work=The Guardian, archived at [[LexisNexis]]|format=fee required|date=12 March 2003|publisher=Guardian News and Media |last=Tremlett|first=Giles|accessdate=2009-11-17 }}</ref>
In 2008 [[Paleontology|palaeontologist]]s discovered an intact specimen of a previously unknown species of [[Sauropoda|sauropod]] [[dinosaur]] at a site near Morella. The animal was believed to have lived in the early [[Cretaceous]] period, approximately 120 million years ago. Funding from wind energy companies and the regional government has aided the excavations and will support a dinosaur museum to be opened at Morella.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/uk/nexis/results/docview/docview.do?docLinkInd=true&risb=21_T7903493418&format=GNBFI&sort=BOOLEAN&startDocNo=1&resultsUrlKey=29_T7903493421&cisb=22_T7903493420&treeMax=true&treeWidth=0&csi=8200&docNo=4 |format=fee required|title='Enormous' dinosaur skeleton found intact|work=The Independent, archived at [[LexisNexis]] |publisher=Independent News and Media |date=28 August 2008|accessdate=2009-11-17|last=Nash|first=Elizabeth }}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery perrow="5"> File:Dominis dels castells que integren el Maestrat històric.png|Dominions of the castles that ruled the historical Maestrazgo </gallery>

revision.text:
{{Infobox mountain | name = Mousa Ali
موسى علي | photo = Mousa Ali.png | photo_caption = Mousa Ali from Djibouti. | elevation_m = 2021 to 2028 | elevation_ref = [http://www.peaklist.org/WWlists/ultras/africa.html Africa Ultra-Prominences, Peaklist.org, listed as "Moussa Ali Terara"] Retrieved 29 September 2011{{cite gvp|vnum=0201-123|name=Mousa Ali|accessdate=2007-04-04}} | prominence_m = 1607 | prominence_ref = [http://www.peakbagger.com/peak.aspx?pid=11143 "Moussa Ali" on Peakbagger] Retrieved 29 September 2011 | map = Djibouti | map_caption = Location of Mousa Ali in Djibouti (on tri-point border with Eritrea and Ethiopia) | map_size = 350 | label_position = right | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|The highest point in Djibouti]]
[[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]] |country={{flag|Djibouti}} |country1={{flag|Ethiopia}} |country2={{flag|Eritrea}} |region=[[Tadjourah Region]] |region1=[[Afar Region]] |region2=[[Southern Red Sea Region]] | range = Denakil | coordinates = {{coord|12|28|07|N|42|24|15|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = [[Stratovolcano]] | age = | last_eruption = [[Holocene]] | first_ascent = 1841 | easiest_route = }} '''Mousa Ali''' ({{lang-ar|موسى علي}}) is a {{Convert|2021|m|ft|0|}} [[stratovolcano]] located on the [[tri-point]] of [[Ethiopia]], [[Eritrea]] and [[Djibouti]]. The volcano is the highest point in Djibouti. The volcano's summit is truncated by a [[caldera]], which contains [[rhyolitic]] [[lava dome]]s and [[lava flow]]s. The last known eruption occurred before the [[Holocene]] era. Mousa Ali is situated at the tri-point of the [[Tadjourah Region]] of [[Djibouti]], the [[Southern Red Sea Region]] of [[Eritrea]], and the [[Afar Region]] of [[Ethiopia]]. ==Geography == [[File:Mousa Ali Relief Map.png|thumb|left|Mousa Ali relief map.]] The mountain has two distinct summits, the higher being the south one with an elevation of 2,021 metres The north summit in Ethiopia has an elevation of 1,871 metres. Both summits are separated by a large caldera, about 1 km (0.71 mi) wide and 1514 metres deep. Mousa Ali, in the northern part of the [[Great Rift Valley]] region, has Eritrea on its northern flank, Ethiopia on the west, and Djibouti the east and south. The Djiboutian town of [[Dorra]] is 36 km to the south-southeast, the Ethiopian volcano Manda-Inakir is 22 km to the southwest, and the road from the Ethiopian town of Manda to the Eritrean port of [[Assab]] is 19 km to the northwest. ==Wildlife and flora== The mountain is home to an abundant amount of wildlife, lush vegetation, flowering shrubs and trees and various plants. ==History== Two sects of [[Afar people|Afar]] live in the area. They are collectively known as Adrúmmi, from 'Adó rum li or "white as Byzantines." The position of Ali Mousa as the tripoint between [[Ethiopia]], [[Eritrea]] and [[Djibouti]] is not the result of an agreement between the three countries. In December 1948 the British administering Eritrea refused to attend a meeting with the other two parties to determine the exact location of their tripoint, set in a 1908 treaty as 60 km inland from the Red Sea. British administration of Eritrea ended in 1952, and with increasing Ethiopian administration over the ensuing decade, and incorporation into Ethiopia from 1962 to 1993, the boundary was internal, not international. In 2002, the Eritrea-Ethiopia Boundary Commission established the tri-point at the Mousa Ali summit;{{cite web |url= http://legal.un.org/riaa/cases/vol_XXV/83-195.pdf |format= PDF |title=Reports of International Arbitral Awards-Decision regarding delimitation of the border between Eritrea and Ethiopia |pages= 167; 179 |author=Eritrea-Ethiopia Boundary Commission |date=2002-04-13 |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=2017-01-20 }} Ethiopia had pressed for it to be further east, nearer to Dadda'to, Djibouti. ==Climate== The temperature of Mousa Ali usually ranges from 7 °C to 19 °C in December and January, and 14 °C to 29 °C from June to September. The weather on the mountain can be very erratic, sometimes severe. {{Weather box|location = Mousa Ali |metric first = yes |single line = yes |Jan high C = 19.6 |Feb high C = 23.5 |Mar high C = 25.7 |Apr high C = 27.1 |May high C = 28.2 |Jun high C = 29.1 |Jul high C = 29.9 |Aug high C = 28.3 |Sep high C = 27.5 |Oct high C = 25.4 |Nov high C = 23.1 |Dec high C = 20.9 |Jan low C = 7.8 |Feb low C = 9.1 |Mar low C = 10.7 |Apr low C = 11.4 |May low C = 12.9 |Jun low C = 14.0 |Jul low C = 15.3 |Aug low C = 13.9 |Sep low C = 12.3 |Oct low C = 10.7 |Nov low C = 9.5 |Dec low C = 9.0 |Jan rain mm = 5 |Feb rain mm = 6 |Mar rain mm = 11 |Apr rain mm = 34 |May rain mm = 39 |Jun rain mm = 6 |Jul rain mm = 6 |Aug rain mm = 53 |Sep rain mm = 47 |Oct rain mm = 13 |Nov rain mm = 9 |Dec rain mm = 13 |source 1 = ''World Weather'' |date=December 2016}} ==See also== * [[List of volcanoes in Eritrea]] * [[List of stratovolcanoes]] * [[List of Ultras of Africa]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{-}} [[Category:International mountains of Africa]] [[Category:Mountains of Djibouti]] [[Category:Mountains of Eritrea]] [[Category:Mountains of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Volcanoes of Djibouti]] [[Category:Volcanoes of Eritrea]] [[Category:Rift volcanoes]] [[Category:Stratovolcanoes of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Stratovolcanoes]] [[Category:Border tripoints]] [[Category:Djibouti–Eritrea border]] [[Category:Djibouti–Ethiopia border]] [[Category:Eritrea–Ethiopia border]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] [[Category:Tadjourah Region]]

revision.text:
<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.svg|191|Coat of arms of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.svg|94|The [[Flag of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]|The [[Coat of arms of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]}} [[Image:LocationSaintVincentAndTheGrenadines.png|thumb|The location of [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]]] [[Image:Saint Vincent and the Grenadines-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines:
'''[[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]''' is a [[List of sovereign states|sovereign]] [[island nation]] located in the [[Lesser Antilles]] [[archipelago]] in the [[Caribbean Sea]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 7, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/vc.html|title=Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> Its {{convert|389|km2|sqmi|0|sing=on}} territory consists of the main island of [[Saint Vincent (island)|Saint Vincent]] and the northern two-thirds of the [[Grenadines]]. The country has a French and [[British Empire|British]] colonial history and is now part of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] and [[Caribbean Community|CARICOM]].
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == <!-- [[image:Saint Vincent and the Grenadines-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]]] --> * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: * Common English country name: [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] * Official English country name: [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] * Common [[endonym]]: [[List of countries and capitals in native languages|Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] * Official endonym: [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states|Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: Name of [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] * [[ISO country codes]]: VC, VCT, 670 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:VC]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.vc]]
== Geography of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines == <!-- [[image:<Topographic Map>|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]]] -->
[[Geography of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] * Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is: ** an [[archipelago]] ** a [[country]] *** an [[island country]] *** a [[nation state]] *** a [[Commonwealth realm]] * Location: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] and [[Western Hemisphere]] *** [[North America]] (though not on the [[mainland]]) ** [[Atlantic Ocean]] *** [[North Atlantic]] **** [[Caribbean]] ***** [[Antilles]] ****** [[Lesser Antilles]] ******* [[Windward Islands]] ******** [[Saint Vincent (island)]] and the northern two-thirds of the [[Grenadines]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[Eastern Caribbean Time]] ([[UTC-04]]) ** Extreme points of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines *** High: [[Soufrière (volcano)|Soufrière]] {{convert|1234|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Caribbean Sea]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: ''none'' ** Coastline: 84 km * [[Population of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]: 120,000 - [[List of countries by population|182nd most populous country]] * * [[Area of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]: 389 * [[:commons:Atlas of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|Atlas of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]
=== Environment of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines === [[Image:Saint Vincent and the Grenadines OnEarth WMS.png|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]]]

revision.comment: Fixed an epigraphic Greek transcription error
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Periplous of the Erythraean Sea.svg|thumb|450x450px|Names, routes and locations of the ''Periplus of the Erythraean Sea'']] The '''''Periplus of the Erythraean Sea''''' or '''''Periplus of the Red Sea''''' ({{lang-grc-koi|Περίπλους τῆς Ἐρυθράς Θαλάσσης}}, {{lang-la|Periplus Maris Erythraei}}) is a [[Greco-Roman world|Greco-Roman]] [[periplus]] written in [[Koine Greek]] that describes navigation and [[Roman commerce|trading opportunities]] from [[Egypt (Roman province)|Roman Egyptian]] ports like [[Berenice Troglodytica]] along the coast of the [[Red Sea]], and others along [[Horn of Africa]], the [[Sindh]] region of [[Pakistan]], along with southwestern regions of [[India]]. The text has been ascribed to different dates between the first and third centuries CE, but a mid-first century date is now the most commonly accepted. While the author is unknown, it is clearly a firsthand description by someone familiar with the area and is nearly unique in providing accurate insights into what the ancient European world knew about the lands around the [[Indian Ocean]]. The ''Erythraean Sea'', or in modern spelling, ''Eritrean Sea'' ({{lang-el|Ἐρυθρά Θάλασσα}}) is presently a Greek name for the Red Sea; to the ancient Greeks it included the Indian Ocean in its entirety and the [[Persian Gulf]]. ==Synopsis== [[File:PeriplusAncientMap.jpg|thumb|200px|17th century map depicting the locations of the ''Periplus of the Erythraean Sea''.]] The work consists of 66 chapters, most of them about the length of a long paragraph in English. For instance, the short Chapter 9 reads in its entirety: {{quote|From Malao ([[Berbera]]) it is two courses to the mart of Moundou, where ships anchor more safely by an island lying very close to the land. The imports to this are as aforesaid [Chapter 8 mentions iron, gold, silver, drinking cups, etc.], and from it likewise are exported the same goods [Chapter 8 mentions myrrh, douaka, makeir, and slaves], and fragrant gum called ''mokrotou'' (cf. [[Sanskrit]] makaranda). The inhabitants who trade here are more stubborn.{{cite book|last1=Hakluyt Society|title=The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea|date=1980|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vpoN9PDYKC4C&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=mokrotou&source=bl&ots=0r_57MpUJq&sig=vO3j8SnB-6poMNHh2cMs3VF7mHc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiBpJ3ar-nWAhUiMJoKHcIIAhMQ6AEIODAC#v=onepage&q=mokrotou&f=false}}}} In many cases, the description of places is sufficiently accurate to identify their present locations; for others, there is considerable debate. For instance, a "[[Rhapta]]" is mentioned as the farthest market down the African coast of "[[Azania]]", but there are at least five locations matching the description, ranging from [[Tanga, Tanzania|Tanga]] to south of the [[Rufiji River]] delta. The description of the Indian coast mentions the [[Ganges River]] clearly, yet after that is somewhat garbled, describing China as a "[[Names of China#Sin|great inland city Thina]]" that is a source of raw [[silk]]. The ''Periplus'' says that a direct sailing route from the Red Sea to the Indian peninsula across the open ocean was discovered by [[Hippalus]] (1st century BCE). Many trade goods are mentioned in the ''Periplus'', but some of the words naming trade goods are seen nowhere else in ancient literature, and so we can only guess as to what they might be. For example, one trade good mentioned is ''"lakkos chromatinos"''. The name ''lakkos'' appears nowhere else in ancient Greek or Roman literature. The name re-surfaces in late medieval Latin as ''lacca'', borrowed from medieval Arabic ''lakk'' in turn borrowed from Sanskritic ''lakh'', meaning [[lac]] i.e. a red-colored resin native to India used as a lacquer and used also as a red colorant.[https://archive.org/stream/sinoiranicachine00laufrich#page/476/mode/1up ''Sino-Iranica''] by Berthold Laufer, year 1919, page 476, footnote 9. Also [https://archive.org/stream/hobsonjobsonglos00yulerich#page/499/mode/1up ''A Glossary of Colloquial Anglo-Indian Words and Phrases''], by Yule and Burnell, year 1903, page 499. Some other named trade goods remain obscure. The ''Periplus'' text derives from a Byzantine 10th-century manuscript in minuscule hand, contained in the collections of the [[University Library Heidelberg]] (CPG 398: 40v-54v), and a copy of it dating from the 14th or 15th century in the British Museum (B.M. Add 19391 9r-12r). In the 10th-century manuscript, the text is attributed to [[Arrian]], probably for no deeper reason than that the manuscript was adjacent to the ''[[Periplus Ponti Euxini]]'' written by him. The ''Periplus'' was edited by [[Sigmund Gelen]] (Zikmund Hruby z Jeleni of [[Prague]])[http://www.vialibri.net/552display/year_1532_1.html "viaLibri Resources for Bibliophiles"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130222104527/http://www.vialibri.net/552display/year_1532_1.html |date=2013-02-22 }} and first published in a modern edition by [[Hieronymus Froben]] in 1533. This edition was corrupt and full of errors but served for later editions for three centuries until the rediscovery of the 10th century [[Heidelberg]] manuscript which was taken to Rome during the [[Thirty Years War]] (1618–1648), then to Paris under [[Napoleon]], and finally returned to Heidelberg in 1816.Schoff (1912), pp. 7, 17. ==Date and authorship== One historical analysis, published by [[Wilfred Harvey Schoff|Schoff]] in 1912, narrowed the date of the text to 59-62 CE,[[Wilfred Harvey Schoff|Schoff]] (1912) "Date and Authorship of the Periplus," pages 7-15. in agreement with present-day estimates of the middle of the 1st century CE.{{cn|date=December 2016}} Schoff additionally provides an historical analysis as to the text's original authorship,Schoff (1912), pages 15-16. and arrives at the conclusion that the author was a "[[Greeks|Greek]] in [[Egypt]], a [[History of Roman Egypt|Roman subject]]."[[Wilfred Harvey Schoff|Schoff]] (1912) "Introduction," page 6. By Schoff's calculations, this would have been during the time of [[Tiberius Claudius Balbilus]] (who coincidentally also was an [[Egypt]]ian [[Greeks|Greek]]). John Hill maintains that the "Periplus can now be confidently dated to between 40 and 70 AD and, probably, between AD 40 and 50."Hill (2009), pp. xvi and 244-245, n. 10.10. Schoff continues by noting that the author could not have been "a highly educated man" as "is evident from his frequent confusion of [[Greek language|Greek]] and [[Latin]] words and his clumsy and sometimes ungrammatical constructions."Schoff (1912), page 16. Because of "the absence of any account of the journey up the [[Nile]] and [[Wadi Hammamat|across the desert]] from [[Coptos]],"Schoff (1912), page 16. Schoff prefers to pinpoint the author's residence to "Berenice rather than [[Alexandria]]."Schoff (1912), page 16. Though Schoff is unclear about which of [[Berenice (disambiguation)|several Berenices]] he is referring to, it is actually [[Berenice Troglodytica]] which is documented, discussed at length and vividly described within the periplus text itself.Please refer to [[Berenice Troglodytica]]. One peculiarity noted by Schoff while translating from the original [[Greek language|Greek]] version is that "the text is so vague and uncertain that [the author] seems rather to be quoting from someone else, unless indeed much of this part of the work has been lost in copying." ==Arabian Peninsula== ===Himyarite kingdom and Saba=== {{Main|Himyarite Kingdom|Sabaeans}} [[File:SouthArabianCoin1stCenturyCE.jpg|thumb|Coin of the [[Himyarite Kingdom]], southern coast of the [[Arabian Peninsula]], in which stopped ships between Egypt and India passed. This is an imitation of a coin of [[Augustus]]. First Century CE.]] Ships from [[Himyarite Kingdom|Himyar]] regularly traveled the East African coast. The ''Periplus of the Erythraean Sea'' describes the trading empire of Himyar and [[Sabaeans|Saba]], regrouped under a single ruler, "Charibael" (Karab Il Watar Yuhan'em II), who is said to have been on friendly terms with [[Rome]]: {{quote|23. And after nine days more there is Saphar, the metropolis, in which lives Charibael, lawful king of two tribes, the [[Homerites]] and those living next to them, called the Sabaites; through continual embassies and gifts, he is a friend of the Emperors.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Paragraph 23.}} ===Frankincense kingdom=== The Frankincense kingdom is described further east along the southern coast of the [[Arabian Peninsula]], with the harbour of Cana (South Arabic ''Qana'', modern [[Bir Ali]] in [[Hadramaut]]). The ruler of this kingdom is named [[Eleazus]], or Eleazar, thought to correspond to King Iliazz Yalit I: {{quote|27. After Eudaemon Arabia there is a continuous length of coast, and a bay extending two thousand stadia or more, along which there are Nomads and Fish-Eaters living in villages; just beyond the cape projecting from this bay there is another market-town by the shore, Cana, of the Kingdom of Eleazus, the Frankincense Country; and facing it there are two desert islands, one called Island of Birds, the other Dome Island, one hundred and twenty stadia from Cana. Inland from this place lies the metropolis Sabbatha, in which the King lives. All the frankincense produced in the country is brought by camels to that place to be stored, and to Cana on rafts held up by inflated skins after the manner of the country, and in boats. And this place has a trade also with the far-side ports, with [[Barygaza]] and [[Scythia]] and [[Ommana]] and the neighboring coast of [[Persia]].|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chap 27}} ==Horn of Africa== ===Somalia=== ====Opone==== {{Main|Opone}} [[Ras Hafun]] in northern [[Somalia]] is believed to be the location of the ancient trade center of [[Opone]]. [[Ancient Egypt]]ian, [[Roman Empire|Roman]] and [[Persian Gulf]] pottery has been recovered from the site by an [[archaeology|archaeological]] team from the [[University of Michigan]]. Opone is in the thirteenth entry of the ''Periplus of the Erythraean Sea'', which in part states: {{quote|And then, after sailing four hundred [[Ancient Greek weights and measures|stadia]] along a promontory, toward which place the [[ocean current|current]] also draws you, there is another market-town called Opone, into which the same things are imported as those already mentioned, and in it the greatest quantity of [[cinnamon]] is produced, (the arebo and moto), and [[slavery|slave]]s of the better sort, which are brought to Egypt in increasing numbers; and a great quantity of [[tortoiseshell material|tortoiseshell]], better than that found elsewhere.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chap.13[http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/ancient/periplus.html Full text, Schoff's 1912 translation]}} In ancient times, Opone operated as a port of call for merchants from [[Phoenicia]], [[Egypt]], [[Greece]], [[Persia]], [[Yemen]], [[Nabataea]], [[Azania]], the [[Roman Empire]] and elsewhere, as it possessed a strategic location along the coastal route from Azania to the [[Red Sea]]. Merchants from as far afield as [[Indonesia]] and [[Malaysia]] passed through Opone, trading spices, silks and other goods, before departing south for [[Jubaland|Azania]] or north to [[Yemen]] or [[Egypt]] on the [[trade route]]s that spanned the length of the [[Indian Ocean]]'s rim. As early as 50 CE, Opone was well known as a center for the cinnamon trade, along with the trading of [[clove]]s and other [[spice]]s, [[ivory]], exotic animal skins and [[incense]]. ====Malao==== {{Main|Malao (ancient)}} The ancient port city of [[Malao (ancient)|Malao]], situated in present-day [[Berbera]] in northwestern Somalia, is also mentioned in the Periplus: {{quote|After Avalites there is another market-town, better than this, called Malao, distant a sail of about eight hundred stadia. The anchorage is an open roadstead, sheltered by a spit running out from the east. Here the natives are more peaceable. There are imported into this place the things already mentioned, and many tunics, cloaks from Arsinoe, dressed and dyed; drinking-cups, sheets of soft copper in small quantity, iron, and gold and silver coin, not much. There are exported from these places myrrh, a little frankincense, (that known as far-side), the harder cinnamon, duaca, Indian copal and macir, which are imported into Arabia; and slaves, but rarely.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chap.8}} ===Aksum Empire=== {{Main|Kingdom of Aksum}} [[File:KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg|thumb|Coins of king [[Endybis]], 227-235 CE. [[British Museum]]. The left one reads in Greek "ΑΞΩΜΙΤΩ ΒΑϹΙΛΕΥϹ", "King of Axum". The right one reads in Greek: "ΕΝΔΥΒΙϹ ΒΑϹΙΛΕΥϹ", "King Endybis".]] Aksum is mentioned in the ''Periplus'' as an important market place for ivory, which was exported throughout the ancient world: {{quote|From that place to the city of the people called Auxumites there is a five days' journey more; to that place all the ivory is brought from the country beyond the Nile through the district called Cyeneum, and thence to Adulis.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chap.4}} According to the ''Periplus'', the ruler of Aksum in the 1st century CE was [[Zoscales]], who, besides ruling in Aksum also held under his sway two harbours on the [[Red Sea]]: [[Adulis]] (near [[Massawa]]) and Avalites ([[Assab]]). He is also said to have been familiar with Greek literature: {{quote|These places, from the Calf-Eaters to the other Berber country, are governed by Zoscales; who is miserly in his ways and always striving for more, but otherwise upright, and acquainted with Greek literature.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chap.5}} ==Southeast Africa== ===Rhapta=== {{Location map | Africa | width = 250px | float = | border = | caption = Supposed location of [[Rhapta]] in [[Africa]] | alt = | relief = yes | AlternativeMap = | overlay_image = | label = [[Rhapta]]
([[Dar es Salaam]]) | label_size = | position = left | background = | mark = | marksize = | link = | lat_deg = -6.8 | lon_deg =39.28 }} Recent research by the [[Tanzania]]n archaeologist Felix Chami has uncovered extensive remains of Roman trade items near the mouth of the [[Rufiji River]] and the nearby [[Mafia Island|Mafia island]], and makes a strong case that the ancient port of [[Rhapta]] was situated on the banks of the Rufiji River just south of [[Dar es Salaam]]. The ''Periplus'' informs us that: {{quote|1=Two runs beyond this island [Menuthias = [[Zanzibar]]?] comes the very last port of trade on the coast of Azania, called [[Rhapta]] ["sewn"], a name derived from the aforementioned sewn boats, where there are great quantities of ivory and tortoise shell.Casson (1989), p. 61.}} Chami summarizes the evidence for Rhapta's location as follows: {{quote|The actual location of the Azanian capital, Rhapta, remains unknown. However, archaeological indicators reported above suggest that it was located on the coast of Tanzania, in the region of the Rufiji River and Mafia Island. It is in this region where the concentration of Panchaea/Azanian period settlements has been discovered. If the island of Menuthias mentioned in the Periplus was [[Zanzibar]], a short voyage south would land one in the Rufiji region. The 2nd century geographer, Ptolemy, locates Rhapta at latitude 8° south, which is the exact latitude of the Rufiji Delta and Mafia Island. The metropolis was on the mainland about one degree west of the coast near a large river and a bay with the same name. While the river should be regarded as the modern Rufiji River, the bay should definitely be identified with the calm waters between the island of Mafia and the Rufiji area. The peninsula east of Rhapta would have been the northern tip of Mafia Island. The southern part of the bay is protected from the deep sea by numerous deltaic small islets separated from Mafia Island by shallow and narrow channels. To the north the bay is open to the sea and any sailor entering the waters from that direction would feel as if he were entering a bay. Even today the residents identify these waters as a bay, referring to it as a 'female sea', as opposed to the more violent open sea on the other side of the island of Mafia.Chami (2002), p. 20.}} In recent years, Felix Chami has found archaeological evidence for extensive Roman trade on Mafia Island and, not far away, on the mainland, near the mouth of the Rufiji River, which he dated to the first few centuries CE. Furthermore, J. Innes Miller points out that Roman coins have been found on [[Pemba Island|Pemba]] island, just north of Rhapta.Miller, J. Innes. 1969. Chapter 8: "The Cinnamon Route". In: The Spice Trade of the Roman Empire. Oxford: University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-814264-1}} Nevertheless, Carl Peters has argued that Rhapta was near modern-day Quelimane in Mozambique,Peters, C., 1902. "The Eldorado of the Ancients", pages 312–319, 347. London: Pearson and Bell citing the fact that (according to the ''Periplus'') the coastline there ran down towards the southwest. Peters also suggests that the description of the "Pyralaoi" (i.e., the "Fire people") – "situated at the entry to the [Mozambique] Channel" – indicates that they were the inhabitants of the volcanic Comoro Islands. He also maintains that Menuthias (with its abundance of rivers and crocodiles) cannot have been Zanzibar; i.e., Madagascar seems more likely. The ''Periplus'' informs us that Rhapta, was under the firm control of a governor appointed by [[Arab]]ian king of Musa, taxes were collected, and it was serviced by "merchant craft that they staff mostly with Arab skippers and agents who, through continual intercourse and intermarriage, are familiar with the area and its language". The Periplus explicitly states that Azania (which included Rhapta) was subject to Charibaêl, the king of both the [[Sabaean]]s and Homerites in the southwest corner of Arabia. The kingdom is known to have been a Roman ally at this period. Charibaêl is stated in the Periplus to be "a friend of the (Roman) emperors, thanks to continuous embassies and gifts" and, therefore, Azania could fairly be described as a vassal or dependency of Rome, just as Zesan is described in the 3rd-century Chinese history, the ''[[Weilüe]]''.William H. Schoff, ''The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea: Travel and Trade in the Indian Ocean by a Merchant of the First Century'' (New York: Longmans, Green, and Co., 1912), Section 23. [http://depts.washington.edu/silkroad/texts/periplus/periplus.html][http://depts.washington.edu/silkroad/texts/weilue/weilue.html#section15 Hill (2004), Section 15] ==Asia== ===Barygaza=== {{Main|Bharuch}} {{Location map | India | width = 250px | float = | border = | caption = Location of [[Barygaza]] in [[India]]. | alt = | relief = yes | AlternativeMap = | overlay_image = | label = [[Barygaza]]
([[Bharuch]]) | label_size = | position = right | background = | mark = | marksize = | link = | lat_deg = 21.71 | lon_deg =72.99 }} Trade with the Indian harbour of [[Barygaza]] is described extensively in the ''Periplus''. [[Nahapana]], ruler of the [[Indo-Scythian]] [[Western Satraps]] is mentioned under the name ''Nambanus'',[http://igmlnet.uohyd.ernet.in:8000/gw_44_5/hi-res/hcu_images/G2.pdf "History of the Andhras"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313210732/http://igmlnet.uohyd.ernet.in:8000/gw_44_5/hi-res/hcu_images/G2.pdf |date=2007-03-13 }} by Durga Prasad as ruler of the area around [[Barigaza]]: [[File:Silver_coin_of_Nahapana_British_Museum.jpg|thumb|Coin of [[Nahapana]] (119–124 CE).
''Obv'': Bust of king Nahapana with a legend in Greek script "ΡΑΝΝΙΩ ΞΑΗΑΡΑΤΑϹ ΝΑΗΑΠΑΝΑϹ", transliteration of the Prakrit ''Raño Kshaharatasa Nahapanasa'': "King Kshaharata Nahapana".]] {{quote|41. Beyond the [[Gulf of Kutch|gulf of Baraca]] is that of [[Bharuch|Barygaza]] and the coast of the country of Ariaca, which is the beginning of the Kingdom of Nambanus and of all India. That part of it lying inland and adjoining Scythia is called [[Abiria]], but the coast is called [[Syrastrene]]. It is a fertile country, yielding wheat and rice and sesame oil and clarified butter, cotton and the Indian cloths made therefrom, of the coarser sorts. Very many cattle are pastured there, and the men are of great stature and black in color. The metropolis of this country is [[Minnagara]], from which much cotton cloth is brought down to Barygaza.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chap. 41}} Under the Western Satraps, Barigaza was one of the main centers of [[Indo-Roman trade relations|Roman trade in the subcontinent]]. The ''Periplus'' describes the many goods exchanged: {{quote|49. There are imported into this market-town (Barigaza), wine, Italian preferred, also [[Laodicea ad Mare|Laodicea]]n and [[Arabia]]n; copper, tin, and lead; coral and topaz; thin clothing and inferior sorts of all kinds; bright-colored girdles a cubit wide; storax, sweet clover, flint glass, [[realgar]], [[antimony]], gold and silver coin, on which there is a profit when exchanged for the money of the country; and ointment, but not very costly and not much. And for the King there are brought into those places very costly vessels of silver, singing boys, beautiful maidens for the harem, fine wines, thin clothing of the finest weaves, and the choicest ointments. There are exported from these places [[spikenard]], costus {{bracket|[[Saussurea costus]]}}, [[bdellium]], ivory, agate and [[carnelian]], [[lycium]], cotton cloth of all kinds, silk cloth, mallow cloth, yarn, long pepper and such other things as are brought here from the various market-towns. Those bound for this market-town from Egypt make the voyage favorably about the month of July, that is Epiphi.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chapter 49.[http://depts.washington.edu/silkroad/texts/periplus/periplus.html The Voyage around the Erythraean Sea], translation with commentary}} Goods were also brought down in quantity from [[Ujjain]], the capital of the Western Satraps: {{quote|48. Inland from this place and to the east, is the city called Ozene, formerly a royal capital; from this place are brought down all things needed for the welfare of the country about Barygaza, and many things for our trade: agate and carnelian, Indian muslins and mallow cloth, and much ordinary cloth.|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, Chapter 48.}} ===Early Chera, Pandyan, and Chola kingdoms=== {{See also|Chera Dynasty|Early Pandyan Kingdom|Muziris|Economy of ancient Tamil country}} {{Location map | India | width = 250px | float = | border = | caption = Location of [[Muziris]] in [[India]]. | alt = | relief = yes | AlternativeMap = | overlay_image = | label =[[Muziris]]
([[Cochin]]) | label_size = | position = right | background = | mark = | marksize = | link = | lat_deg = 9.97 | lon_deg =76.28 }} The lost port city of [[Muziris]] (Near present day [[Cochin]]) in the [[Chera Dynasty|Chera kingdom]], as well as the [[Early Pandyan Kingdom]] are mentioned in the ''Periplus'' as major centers of trade, pepper and other spices, metal work and [[semiprecious]] stones, between [[Damirica]] and the [[Roman Empire]]. According to the ''Periplus'', numerous Greek seamen managed an intense trade with Muziris: {{quote|Then come Naura ([[Kannur]]) and [[Tyndis]], the first markets of [[Damirica]] or Limyrike, and then Muziris and Nelcynda, which are now of leading importance. [[Tyndis]] is of the [[Chera dynasty|Kingdom of Cerobothra]]; it is a village in plain sight by the sea. Muziris, of the same kingdom, abounds in ships sent there with cargoes from [[Arabia]], and by the [[Greeks|Greek]]s; it is located on a river (River [[Kaveri River|Periyar]]), distant from Tyndis by river and sea five hundred stadia, and up the river from the shore twenty stadia. Nelcynda is distant from Muziris by river and sea about five hundred stadia, and is of another Kingdom, [[Early Pandyan Kingdom|the Pandian]]. This place also is situated on a river, about one hundred and twenty stadia from the sea ...|The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, 53–54}} Damirica or Limyrike is [[Ancient Tamil country|Tamilagam]] (Tamil தமிழகம்) – the "[[Ancient Tamil country|Tamil country]]". Further, this area served as a hub for trade with the interior, in the Gangetic plain: {{quote|Besides this there are ex-ported great quantities of fine pearls, ivory, silk cloth, spikenard from the Ganges, malabathrum from the places in the interior, transparent stones of all kinds, diamonds and sapphires, and tortoise-shell; that from Chryse Island, and that taken among the islands along the coast of Damirica (Limyrike). They make the voyage to this place in a favorable season who set out from Egypt about the month of July, that is Epiphi.|The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, 56}} ===Indo-Tibet Border=== The ''Periplus'' also describes the annual fair in present-day Northeast India, on the border with Tibet. {{quote|Every year there turns up at the border of Thina a certain tribe, short in body and very flat-faced ... called Sêsatai ... They come with their wives and children bearing great packs resembling mats of green leaves and then remain at some spot on the border between them and those on the Thina side, and they hold a festival for several days, spreading out the mats under them, and then take off for their own homes in the interior.|Periplus, Chap. 65{{harv|Casson|1989|pp=51–93}}}} Sêsatai''Besatae'' in the Schoff translation and also sometimes used by Ptolemy, they are a people similar to Kirradai and they lived in the region between "Assam and Sichuan" {{harv|Casson|1989|pp=241–242}} are the source of ''[[malabathron]]''. {{quote|The [? locals], counting on this, then turn up in the area, collect what the Sêsatai had spread out, extract the fibers from the reeds, which are called ''petroi'', and lightly doubling over the leaves and rolling them into ball-like shapes, they string them on the fibers from the reeds. There are three grades: what is called big-ball malabathron from the bigger leaves; medium-ball from the lesser leaves; and small-ball from the smaller. Thus three grades of malabathron are produced, and then they are transported into India by the people who make them.|Periplus, Chap 65}} ===Remains of the Indo-Greek kingdom=== [[File:MenanderAndReverse.JPG|thumb|The ''Periplus'' explains that coins of the [[Indo-Greek]] king [[Menander I]] were current in Barigaza.]] The ''Periplus'' claims that Greek buildings and wells exist in [[Bharuch|Barigaza]], falsely attributing them to [[Alexander the Great]], who never went this far south. This account of a kingdom tracing its beginnings to Alexander's campaigns and the Hellenistic [[Seleucid empire]] that followed: {{quote|The metropolis of this country is Minnagara, from which much cotton cloth is brought down to Barygaza. In these places there remain even to the present time signs of the expedition of Alexander, such as ancient shrines, walls of forts and great wells.|Periplus, Chap. 41}} The ''Periplus'' further claims to the circulation of Indo-Greek coinage in the region: {{quote|To the present day ancient drachmae are current in Barygaza, coming from this country, bearing inscriptions in Greek letters, and the devices of those who reigned after Alexander, [[Apollodotus II|Apollodorus]] {{sic}} and [[Menander I|Menander]].|Periplus Chap. 47}} The Greek city of [[Alexandria Bucephalous]] on the [[Jhelum River]] is mentioned in the ''Periplus'', as well as in the Roman [[Peutinger Table]]: {{quote|The country inland of [[Barigaza]] is inhabited by numerous tribes, such as the Arattii, the Arachosii, the Gandaraei and the people of Poclais, in which is Bucephalus Alexandria|Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, 47}} ==See also== * [[Silk Road]] * [[Indo-Roman trade relations]] ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Casson |first=Lionel |authorlink=Lionel Casson |title=The Periplus Maris Erythraei: Text With Introduction, Translation, and Commentary |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qQWYkSs51rEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=774+787+srivijaya&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjX55q698vOAhVMIsAKHWluBVM4MhDoAQg3MAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate= |year=1989 |publisher=Princeton University Press |location= |isbn=0-691-04060-5 |page= |pages=}} * Chami, F. "Le Periple et l'histoire politique del'Inde". ''Journal Asiatique'' 279 (1991):31-38. * Robin, C. 1991. "L'Arabie du sud et la date du Périple de la mer érythrée". ''Journal Asiatique'' 279:1-30. * Dr. Nagaswamy, R. 1995 ''Roman Karur''. Brahadish Publications. https://web.archive.org/web/20120507185123/http://tamilartsacademy.com/books/roman%20karur/cover.html * Schoff, Wilfred Harvey, translator and Secretary of the [[Philadelphia Civic Center|Commercial Museum of Philadelphia]], with a foreword by W. P. Wilson, Sc. Director, [[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology|The Philadelphia Museums]]. ''Periplus of the Erythraean Sea: Travel and Trade in the Indian Ocean by a Merchant of the First Century, Translated from the Greek and Annotated.'' (First published 1912, New York, New York: Longmans, Green, and Co.) Reprinted 1995, New Delhi: Munshiram Monoharlal Publishers, {{ISBN|81-215-0699-9}} . {{refend}} ==External links== {{wikisource}} *''The Periplus of the Erythrean sea, containing an account of the navigation of the ancients, from the sea of Suez to the coast of Zanguebar'', William Vincent (ed.), 2 voll., London, 1800, [https://books.google.com/books?id=d1dBAAAAcAAJ vol. 1], [https://books.google.com/books?id=lldBAAAAcAAJ vol. 2]. *''[https://archive.org/details/arrianialexandr00dietgoog Arriani alexandrini periplus maris erythraei]'', B. Fabricius, Dresdae, de commissis H. M. Gottschalcki, 1849. *''Geographi graeci minores'', [[Karl Otfried Müller]], Paris, editoribus Firmin-Didot et sociis, 1882, [https://archive.org/stream/geographigraeci00mueluoft#page/256/mode/2up vol. 1 pp. 257-305]. * William H. Schoff, ''[http://depts.washington.edu/silkroad/texts/periplus/periplus.html The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea: Travel and Trade in the Indian Ocean by a Merchant of the First Century]'' (New York: Longmans, Green, and Co., 1912), with additional commentary including alternate spellings or translations from Lionel Casson's more recent edition. * [http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/ancient/periplus.html Ancient history sourcebook]: The basic text from Schoff's 1912 translation. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Periplus, Erythraean Sea}} [[Category:1st-century books]] [[Category:Foreign relations of ancient Rome]] [[Category:Classical geography]] [[Category:Africa–India relations]] [[Category:History of Pakistan]] [[Category:Periplus of the Erythraean Sea| ]] [[Category:History of the Red Sea]]

[[File:Sindh in Pakistan (claims hatched).svg|thumb|Location of modern Sindh in Pakistan.]] '''Sigerdis''' is a name given by the ancient Greeks to a part of the northwestern [[South Asia]]. It seems to correspond to the ''Sindhu'', the delta of the [[Indus]] river, today's area of [[Sindh]] in southern [[Pakistan]].
Referring to the conquests of the Indo-Greeks in the 2nd century BCE, [[Strabo]] writes that:
:"The Greeks... took possession, not only of [[Patalene|Patalena]], but also, on the rest of the coast, of what is called the kingdom of [[Saraostus]] and '''Sigerdis'''. In short, Apollodorus says that Bactriana is the ornament of Ariana as a whole; and, more than that, they extended their empire even as far as the [[Seres]] and the [[Phryni]]." (Strabo 11.11.1 {{ref|Strabo}})
==Notes== #{{note|Strabo}} Strabo 11.11.1 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Strab.+11.11.1 Full text]
{{coord missing|Pakistan}}
[[Category:Ancient Greek language]] [[Category:Geography of India]] [[Category:Indus River]] [[Category:Geography of Sindh]] [[Category:Geography of Pakistan]]
{{Pakistan-geo-stub}}

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Country subdivisions of Africa to [[:Category:Country subdivisions in Africa]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
[[File:Un-guinea.png|thumb|650px|Guinea's natural regions of Maritime, [[Middle Guinea|Middle]], [[Upper Guinea|Upper]], and [[Guinée Forestière|Forested]].]] [[Guinea]] is divided into four [[natural region]]s with distinct human, geographic, and climatic characteristics: * Maritime Guinea (''La Guinée Maritime'') covers 18% of the country * [[Middle Guinea]] (''La Moyenne-Guinée'') covers 20% of the country * [[Upper Guinea]] (''La Haute-Guinée'') covers 38% of the country * [[Guinée Forestière|Forested Guinea]] (''Guinée Forestière'') covers 23% of the country, and is both forested and mountainous == Government divisions == === Regions === {{See|Regions of Guinea}} [[File:Guinea Regions.png|thumb|350px|[[Regions of Guinea]].]] Guinea is divided into seven [[Regions of Guinea|administrative regions]]. The national capital, Conakry, ranks as a special zone. {|class="wikitable" |- !Region!!Capital!!Area (km2!!Population (2014 census) |- |[[Conakry Region]] ||[[Conakry]]|| 450 || 1,660,973 |- |[[Nzérékoré Region]] ||[[Nzérékoré]]|| 37,658 || 1,527,030 |- |[[Kankan Region]] ||[[Kankan]]|| 72,145 || 1,972,537 |- |[[Kindia Region]] ||[[Kindia]]|| 28,873 || 1,561,374 |- |[[Boké Region]] ||[[Boké]]|| 31,186 || 1,083,147 |- |[[Labé Region]] ||[[Labé]]|| 22,869 || 994,458 |- |[[Faranah Region]] ||[[Faranah]]|| 35,581 || 941,554 |- |[[Mamou Region]]||[[Mamou]] || 17,074 || 731,188 |} *The capital [[Conakry]] with a population of 1,660,973 ranks as a special zone === Prefectures === {{See|Prefectures of Guinea}} Guineas regions are subdivided into [[Prefectures of Guinea|thirty-three prefectures]]. [[Image:Guinea Prefectures.png|thumb|350px|[[Prefectures of Guinea]].]] {{col-begin|width=auto}} {{col-3}}

{{col-3}} {{col-end}} === Sub-prefectures === {{See|Sub-prefectures of Guinea}} The Communes of Guinea or sub prefectures, known in French as ''sous-prefectures'', are the third-level administrative divisions in [[Guinea]]. As of 2009 there were 303 rural communes of Guinea and 38 urban communes, 5 of which compose the [[Conakry]] greater urban area. [[File:Sub-prefectures of Guinea.jpg|650px]] == See also == * [[Geography of Guinea]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Guinea topics}} {{Africa topic|Subdivisions of}} [[Category:Subdivisions of Guinea| ]] [[Category:Country subdivisions by country|Guinea]] [[Category:Natural regions]] [[Category:Country subdivisions in Africa|Guinea]]

[[File:Stockholm_boroughs_2007.svg|thumb|Söderort includes the southern boroughs of Stockholm.]] [[File:Johanneshov, flygfoto 2014-09-20.jpg|thumb|Typical 1940-era homes in {{ill|Årsta district|lt=Årsta|sv|Årsta}}. Picture south with {{ill|Slakthusområdet|sv}} and the Globe area to the left of the top edge.]] '''Söderort''' (literally "the southern place", sometimes translated to ''South Stockholm'') is the southern suburban part of the [[Stockholm Municipality]], [[Sweden]]. It is also part of the city of [[Stockholm]]. == Geography == Söderort is located in the northern part of the [[Södertörn]] peninsula/island. The boroughs of Söderort are: [[Enskede-Årsta-Vantör]], [[Farsta (borough)|Farsta]], [[Hägersten-Liljeholmen]], [[Skärholmen (borough)|Skärholmen]], [[Skarpnäck (borough)|Skarpnäck]] and [[Älvsjö (borough)|Älvsjö]]. == History == The main part of Söderort was annexed by the ''City of Stockholm'' in 1913. Since 2007, Söderort is organized into six ''stadsdelsområden'' (sometimes translated to [[Boroughs of Stockholm|boroughs]]): [[Enskede-Årsta-Vantör]], [[Farsta]], [[Hägersten-Liljeholmen]], [[Skarpnäck (borough)|Skarpnäck]], [[Skärholmen]], and [[Älvsjö]].City of Stockholm: [http://stockholm.se/-/English/Stockholm-by-districts/ "Stockholm by districts"] Before 2007, it was organized into eight ''stadsdelsområden'': [[Enskede-Årsta]], [[Farsta (borough)|Farsta]], [[Hägersten (borough)|Hägersten]], [[Liljeholmen (borough)|Liljeholmen]], [[Skarpnäck (borough)|Skarpnäck]], [[Skärholmen (borough)|Skärholmen]], [[Vantör (borough)|Vantör]] and [[Älvsjö (borough)|Älvsjö]]. == Districts == {| border |-bgcolor=#dddddd !District !!
